150884219.review:
[b] 8.5/10 [/b]. This game still holds up years after its release. Visually stunning with meticulous attention to detail, [i] Alien: Isolation [/i] captures the essence of the original film, bringing Sevastopol Station to life in a way that will leave you in awe and fear. The game's commitment to authenticity, coupled with its strategic gameplay, results in a heart-racing adventure that keeps you on edge from start to finish.

This 2014 release is a love letter to Ridley Scott's iconic science fiction horror film, and it stands out as one of the most immersive and terrifying gaming experiences ever crafted. This is in no small part to its faithful replication of the aesthetic and design of [i] Alien [/i], nostalgic retro-futuristic technology and spine-chilling noises the Xenomorph makes as it stalks you throughout the station, every element contributes to an atmosphere that's incredibly immersive and tense.

From the moment you step into the claustrophobic halls of the space station, the game envelops you in an atmosphere of sheer dread. The attention to detail is staggering; the flickering lights, ominous hums, and distant echoes all contribute to an unsettling ambience that keeps you on the edge of your seat. Navigating through these environments requires strategy and resourcefulness, as the threat of the Xenomorph looms around every corner. The non-linear structure encourages exploration, and the game rewards players who take the time to uncover the station's secrets and lore.

The attention to detail in the environments, and the lighting effects contribute significantly to the game's oppressive atmosphere. The sound design is equally impressive, with the iconic hisses and screeches of the Xenomorph sending shivers down your spine. The haunting musical score complements the visuals perfectly, adding an extra layer of tension to an already nerve-racking experience.

Another aspect that sets this game apart is the A.I. behaviour of the Xenomorph. Unlike other horror games where the enemy's behaviour is predictable, the Alien in this game is a dynamic and adaptive adversary. It learns from your actions, making each encounter a unique and nerve-wracking experience. The tension peaks as you desperately try to outsmart this relentless hunter, using the environment to your advantage or simply holding your breath, praying it doesn't hear you. So however you choose to explore the station, try not to make too much noise...

If you're a fan of the [i] Alien [/i] franchise or just love a good, heart-pounding horror experience, this is a must-play. It is perhaps the best [i] Alien [/i] game out there and still have a large following that continues to attract new fans. It's a true testament to the power of interactive storytelling and a shining example of what survival horror games can achieve when by a dedicated team who deserve the chance to develop a sequel.

150558824.review:
Nearly a decade since its release, Alien Isolation stands as a testament to the enduring power of exceptional game design. This survival horror masterpiece continues to set the gold standard for the genre, delivering an intense and nerve-wracking experience that captivates players from start to finish.

From the moment you step into the hauntingly atmospheric Sevastopol space station, the game envelops you in an unnerving ambiance that pays homage to the original Alien film. The attention to detail in both the visuals and audio design creates an immersive and claustrophobic atmosphere, intensifying the sense of dread as you navigate the station's dark corridors.

What truly sets Alien Isolation apart is the relentless and unpredictable AI of the Xenomorph. The alien isn't just a scripted threat; it learns, adapts, and hunts you with a level of sophistication that keeps the tension at a constant high. This dynamic element elevates the game beyond a mere horror experience, creating genuine moments of terror and panic.

Even after almost a decade, Alien Isolation's graphics, sound design, and gameplay mechanics hold up remarkably well. The commitment to crafting a true-to-source horror experience ensures that this game remains a standout title in the genre.

In summary, Alien Isolation is a timeless gem that continues to be a pinnacle of horror and thriller gaming. Whether you're a fan of the Alien franchise or simply seeking a spine-chilling adventure, this game is an absolute must-play that has rightfully earned its place among the best in the genre.

150301839.review:
Short version: 
Alien Isolation is a mixed bag of solid gameplay mechanics, excellent atmosphere, legitimately intimidating enemies, and a series of absolutely FRUSTRATING breaks in immersion along the way. The first time I tried to play Isolation, I uninstalled it halfway through the medical wing.  The second time I pushed through it because the parts of the game that I liked felt like they were worth revisiting.  In the end I beat the game, and I'm putting a yes on checking this game out, but I strongly recommend you wait for a sale.  It's not worth full price. 


Long version: Alien Isolation gets several things right and those deserve their spotlight in addition to the issues and frustrations.  First off, the good: 

All but two of the enemy types are well designed.  The Working Joe's, the other survivors, Seegson Security, you name it, they all have ways by which you can bypass them to get through an area, or take the fight directly to them if you're desperate.  Generally speaking however, you're a squishy little engineer and they're either tougher than you, stronger than you, or both, so the game strongly encourages you to avoid them if at all possible and gives you more tools to that effect than for fighting.  Flares, noisemakers, smoke bombs, the gadgets in the game each have specific purposes and enemy types they're effective against, and the game's generous in giving you enough materials to craft everything you could want as long as you're not spamming like a maniac.  The few combat options you do get ARE effective, so it's worth making sure you have those reserves on hand. And the way the game gives you some options and then makes it clear that they have dangerous consequences, so you're always considering them but more often than not end up not using them out of worry?  It's a stellar example of managing player expectations on the design side.

Early-game level design is simply fantastic.  Between the map and the motion tracker's built-in compass you never get lost, but you'll be surprised at how rarely you need it in the early parts of the game.  The hallways make it feel like you could get lost, but are actually very linear in where you can and can't go and the lighting is designed in such a way as to guide you if you start to feel stuck.  It's an extremely effective atmosphere and further adds to the tension in the equally stellar audio design.  In addition, by using save points throughout the game, the devs found a way to ensure that you as the player have tension buildup - how long has it been since your last one?  How much progress will get ruined if you die now?  Better be careful, you actually have something invested that you can lose.  It adds intimidation factors for all but the two enemy types I briefly mentioned earlier, which I'll get to in the cons section. 

Story and writing wise, it makes perfect sense - people vanishing to a mysterious killer, everyone for themselves, a dying facility, and one scared woman cut off from her escape route by an accident, trying to find answers in the middle of it all.  Each of the characters met along the way are solidly written; a couple are there just for exposition, but even those have personality and motivations that don't necessarily mesh with the rest of the cast. The puzzles to solve and the slow actions for certain types of activities all make it feel like you have a need to rush before getting caught, further adding to the atmosphere, and while it wasn't necessary that the actions had contextual button presses to synchronize with it, I would certainly say they added to the immersion of you being in Amanda's shoes and taking those actions directly. 


But for the bad: 

The worst part of the game is, ironically, the alien itself.  The Xenomorph and Facehuggers instakill you if they catch you.  No escape, no recourse.  You have fire weapons which can scare off the Xeno, and the Facehuggers can be killed by basically any ranged weapon in your arsenal, but that doesn't excuse the xeno's ability to spot and rush you before you have time to even react or figure out what you did wrong for the next attempt - or worse, round a corner and run into it yourself because it stopped moving long enough for the motion tracker to lose it and make you think it went into a vent.  There are entire GUIDES written about how to deal with the Xeno, on reddit and beyond, because it's got this "horror director" algorithm that changes its behavior constantly so you can never properly predict it - cool in some cases, but more often than not it makes the Xeno come right back 10 seconds after leaving so you don't even have time to act.  And the number of times it will stand directly in the way of your objective so you have to sit and wait, when the game's trying to encourage you to keep moving? Well, I lost count of mine, let's put it that way. 

In the lategame, the level design loses a lot of that early guide-aid and becomes more aggravating.  Up one ramp, down another, through this transit to load a new map and straight into an elevator that loads ANOTHER new map!  It almost feels like going through a Metroidvania game - except you're not exploring to unlock anything, you're trying to get from Point A to Point B as efficiently as possible before you're instagibbed again. And there's one room in particular where four doors you have to double back across multiple times and have difficulty knowing which door to go through when as there's nothing but the compass to go off, while trying to avoid an idiot with a gun who will call the Xeno by shooting at you if he so much as spots you. 

And last but not least: It just.... keeps.... going.  There's two scenes where you're going around in a spacesuit and the walk pace is so painfully slow that what you could cross in 15 seconds with a sprint takes 4-5 minutes in these segments.  It's unnecessary, and made worse by the fact that literally nothing happens while you're in suit, so you're just Holding W and waiting to get to your next turn or objective.  You could literally weigh down the W key and navigate with your mouse one-handed.  That's bad design.  And the number of false endings would make LOTR: Return of the King jealous!

Anger crushes fear.  Frustration breaks immersion.  A horror game cannot afford to cause either of these emotions on a consistent basis, and yet that's exactly what happens in Alien Isolation.  The parts of the game that are good are really, REALLY good, and I will praise those elements all day long.  But the parts of the game that are bad are really, REALLY bad, and they hold back the good elements from being utterly fantastic.

Perhaps your experience will differ from mine; maybe you'll figure out the secret formula of the Xeno Algorithm and bypass the headaches that bothered myself and many other players.  Regardless, my recommendation is that you do consider checking this game out - but only get it on a discount.  It's worth trying for the parts that are good, but it's not worth full price.

150108522.review:
[h1]Briefly about pros and cons:[/h1]
[b]+ immersiveness
+ a good fanservice with respect to the original
+ atmospheric locations
+ relatively smart opponents
+ soundtrack

- the second half of the game has backtracking, and it was sometimes difficult for me to navigate the station
- the plot tries very carefully to fit into the canon, and does not introduce much that is new. A minor drawback in my opinion.
- my personal pain is that the game does not have trading cards :(
[/b]

[h1]Detailed overview:[/h1]

Alien Isolation is the perfect movie game. I have never seen the atmosphere of a film conveyed so accurately. In this regard, quite a large part of the fun of the game can be obtained only if you are familiar with the original source. From the very beginning, we get to the fanservice location - a ship of the same model as the Nostromo. To wander through its compartments is already an incredible experience. But this is just the beginning and the most interesting will begin a little later, but for now we will be given the necessary minimum of exposure and thrown into a new location - the Sevastopol station, which was already planned to be decommissioned. This is a fairly large, relatively open location. The interior of the station is based on the style of the first film and perfectly copes with the task of narration through the environment. Despite the constant danger, I regularly stayed at the locations to wander and see all the details. I think it's worth stopping the discussion of the visual on the fact that the graphics due to the stylistics look nice to this day (which cannot be said about the facial animation).

What besides the atmosphere makes this game my favorite survival horror? Of course, hide-and-seek and confrontation with various opponents. The developers logically assumed that running exclusively from xenomorphs for several hours would get bored pretty quickly. The setting allowed us to add not only androids who decided not to follow the laws of robotics and became contentedly frightening, although not as immortal and unstoppable as xenomorphs. There are also quite a lot of people left at the station, most of whom do not really want you to move around their territory and are ready to shoot anyone who comes too close. The crafting system is responsible for survival in this aggressive environment, the interface of which, by the way, looks as stylish as everything in this game. You can craft small devices that can facilitate the passage. There are also weapons that allow you to stay alive in a critical situation, but no more. Even a flamethrower can only force the xenomorph to retreat, and if you do not hide, the enraged alien will return with an even greater desire to kill. This allows you to solve game problems in various ways, but always reminds you that the safest option is stealth. And even though I can't call it the best stealth, it's pretty close to that. At least the AI system adds to the interest, which seriously changes depending on the level of complexity. The plot, though quite simple, as in the film, is based on survival. Yes, sometimes backtracking is a little confusing. I have often found parallels with Prey, where the map hardly helps in the search. The absence of a global map of the station can completely lead to frustration, the benefit is that you can quickly understand that you are not where you should be.

All this makes this game one of the few where every aspect is performed at such a high level that nothing distracts you from the gameplay and you get exactly the emotions that you should.

9/10

149919997.review:
I played Alien: Isolation in October of 2016. I didn't finish it, but that's not important. Look, I'm a coward. I'm not going to hide it. You have to know that going into what follows.

The game terrified me. It was the most upsetting video gaming experience of my life. Why haven't I reviewed this game until now, 7 years since I played it? Because it still unsettles me to think about it. In nearly every moment of play, there's an aura of worry. Why is everything so dark? Why do the lights flash irregularly? Why is the music so tense? Why are creepy androids patrolling around, violently condemning my presence? Why why why?

And then there's the alien. Singular. Just the one. There might as well have been hundreds. I worried about every corner, every shadow. I spent more time imagining the enemy's possible presence than actually seeing it, yet I was consistently on edge. You know you're never going to kill it--its name is the game's title, after all--so you run and hide and sweat and consider turning off the game, but ha ha, it's just pixels, keep on going. Each new room becomes nothing but an opportunity for the alien to show up and terrify you. In my case, the playthrough was mostly sneaking from bleak hallway to darkened passage, wishing I'd brought anyone along to keep me company.

Okay, that word: "playthrough." At least a quarter of my time in the game was spent hiding in a locker, trying to psych myself up to advance through the levels. I put pictures of puppies on my second monitor. I tried talking to a friend. I just frowned a lot, reminding myself that video games are fun.

Did I turn my room's overhead light on four minutes in? Yes. Did I put my headphones on my shoulders rather than my ears? Yes. Did I yelp in terror at a wafting smoke plume, imagining it to be the alien come to consume me? ...  I don't want to answer that.

Let me be clear: in the 8 hours I played A:I, I saw the alien probably ... twice. Three times, maybe. But that doesn't matter. Any game that allows the player to be so immersed in its environment that the lurking horror's absence is perhaps scarier than its presence has pulled off a feat. Its greatest terrors weren't in the game world; they were in me.

Is this the scariest game ever made? I don't know. I don't want to know.

Recommended.

149588754.review:
Me ha parecido un juego muy bueno. A continuación voy a destacar los que, para mí, son los mejores aspectos de este.

- Ambientación y fidelidad al universo "Alien": Este juego se desarrolla en el mismo universo que las películas de "Alien" y captura fielmente la atmósfera claustrofóbica y aterradora de la franquicia. El transcurso de la historia gira en torno a una estación espacial llamada Sevastopol, que ha caído en el caos después de un brote de Xenomorfos.

- Jugabilidad de supervivencia: El juego se centra en la supervivencia, asumiremos el papel de Amanda Ripley, la hija de Ellen Ripley, en su búsqueda de respuestas sobre la desaparición de su madre. Habrá que utilizar sigilo y recursos limitados para evitar tanto al Xenomorfo como a otros peligros que acechan en la estación.

- La inteligencia artificial del Xenomorfo: Este enemigo es impredecible y aprende de las acciones del jugador, lo que hace que cada encuentro sea una experiencia tensa y aterradora.

- Elementos de sigilo: En el juego, habrá que moverse en silencio, esconderse y utilizar objetos para distraer al Xenomorfo y otros enemigos. La gestión de recursos es esencial para sobrevivir.

- Gráficos y sonido: Para ser un juego de 2014, cuenta con una impresionante calidad gráfica y una banda sonora que contribuye a crear una atmósfera de terror. El sonido juega un papel fundamental para alertarte de la presencia del Xenomorfo y crear una experiencia inmersiva.

- Narrativa y personajes: La trama del juego se desarrolla a medida que Amanda Ripley busca respuestas sobre la desaparición de su madre y los eventos en la estación Sevastopol. Los personajes que se encuentran en el juego contribuyen a la historia y al sentido de peligro constante.

En resumen, tanto si eres un fanático de la saga o eres alguien cuyo primer contacto con esta franquicia ha sido este videojuego (al igual que yo), te recomiendo jugarlo, no te arrepentirás.

149023771.review:
I'm a massive Alien fan, having adored the series since I was a homunculus, but I missed out on Alien: Isolation initially due to (at the time) not hearing about its release. I played this game a couple months off release on the Xbox One, but never finished it. Came back to it and finished it on PC, and can safely say that this is the greatest Alien game ever made, and a masterpiece of horror.

Alien: Isolation does an absolutely phenomenal job with its worldbuilding, audio design, and claustrophobic gameplay. The developers clearly cared about the original series, with the game looking as if it was directly from the original film. The audio and musical score is amazingly tense, filling the player with dread as they clamber through vents and craft pipe bombs with spare parts.
The star of the game, the Alien, is by far one of the most engaging, terrifying, and wondrous enemies I have ever encountered in a game. At no point does the Alien become boring: even after hours of the campaign and replaying levels for speedrunning certain sections, the Alien never became uninteresting. This, to me, is the most important aspect of the game: the core gameplay of hiding from the Alien is incredibly tense and amazingly terror-inducing. To this day, the Alien's ability to amaze me with its horrible intelligence has yet to be topped by another horror game. 

Besides the Alien, the game's combat and stealth is really well done. The Working Joe robots are freaky and do a good job of serving as a secondary antagonist, and although the human sections can get a bit frustrating on the hardest difficulty (while playing pacifist, in fairness), they're still fun to see, and you can always whack your jack on a wall to summon the starbeast as backup.

The story isn't particularly special, but it's still pretty engaging, especially for an Alien title. Nothing too complicated, but it's fun and there are plenty of great callbacks for Alien fans (including a remake of the original LV426 derelict), and the game stays fun throughout. Some might say that it can have a bit of a slow start before the Alien is in full force, or that the campaign can drag on a bit, but I can't say I agree. Best of all, the two DLCs for the game let you play through two iconic situations from the original film, with the original actors reprising their roles as voices in audio logs and gameplay. It's pretty fun.

Overall, I'd say this game is a modern classic, and ought to be considered as one of the best horror games ever made. It's a lovingly crafted gift, dedicated to Alien fans and horror enthusiasts alike. Although it's a shame that it got a lukewarm reception on release, its quality has been better appreciated over time, and I hope that by playing it, (you) can see how great it really is. 
You can buy it on sale, since it goes for cheap often, but I'd 100% endorse purchasing it at full price. The two story based DLC are also highly worth it if you're an Alien fan. The other DLC are challenge levels, so it really depends on whether you enjoy that gamemode and want more variety in the levels. If you ask me, buy the game and both story DLC: you won't regret it!

And when you first beat an android finally, it feels so rewarding. Everything about this game just makes you want to come back to it. I love this. 10/10.

Ripley, Signing Off

Stuck on a single space station. you're left feeling confined in places to run and hide, all while being hunted down by not justr Humans and Androids, but a 6ft, Nimble, Xenomorph, that chases you throughout the entire game and cannot be killed, only leaving you with the choice of scaring it away by fire, or hiding underneath or inside objects. 148621487.review:
As a fan of the Alien franchise and everything that is sci-fi and space, I cannot find a better word to describe the game other than simply calling it a masterpiece. Alien isolation absolutely nails the atmosphere of the first Alien movie, using exquisite sound and graphic design, from the unsettling creaking of the sevastopol station and other environmental sounds to the alternation of very dark and very bright areas. The game is full of visual cues to the near constant threat of the creature, and its heavy steps as it stalks you, bear witness to its overwhelming deadliness. 

I played the game on hard as is recommended by the developers and I found it to be a terrifying but fair experience. I caught myself quite a few times having a heavy heartbeat and needing to take a small break to relax. The joy of reaching a save station after crouching around a crate  for a few minutes as the Xenomorph searches the room for you, is genuine and keeps you going, objective after objective. BTW, as other people have said, don't hide in lockers for too long, they are death traps. It's much better to move around a piece of furniture and swiftly pursue your next objective when the coast is clear. 

Story wise, there aren't a lot of new perspectives to be gained, but IMO that's beyond the scope of the game anyway. Just enjoy it as the massive fan service that it is (but with great gameplay!). If OTOH you're a horror fan but not familiar with the franchise, what are you doing with your life? Go watch at least the first two movies and the assembly cut of Alien 3! Then play Alien Isolation!

148456469.review:
I enjoyed this game overall, but it should have been shorter in my opinion. Altough I found that some sequences are masterpieces, I found some others to be bland, and I couldn't play through these without a few day of pause inbetween. 

The cause of this is that the gameplay is honestly not the best. Crouch, wait, press on buttons, go where the map tells you to go, occasionally spit some fire, pickup some items which aren't very useful (I think I haven't used a single craftable item in my playthrough except medikits), ...

But the atmosphere and sound design of this game were simply amazing. This game absolutely nailed the horror part imo. I think I had a nightmare about these damn androids. The alien is a constant source of fear, although it becomes less of a threat once you understand how to play around it, and even less after unlocking the flamethrower, as you then get a ton of opportunities to scare the alien away yourself.

In the end, not the best horror game, but one of the scariest one. Yet ambiance alone cannot carry a game. I still recommend it if you're a horror game enthusiast, but don't expect the best game ever (like a 7/10, or something like that, I don't know).

One of the best horror games of all time. It has the smartest and most convincing enemy AI ever made without being broken, with the Alien using an arsenal of evolving strategies to make you respect its place in the food chain above you.

You have to keep moving and using every resource available alongside your intuition in order to survive. 148063356.review:
This is one of the quintessential games for a horror game enthusiast.  Not only is it the definitive interactive Alien experience, it is one of the most frightening horror games of all time. (minor spoilers included)

Atmosphere and Sound engineering 10/10 - the audio work on this game is exceptional and will entirely draw you into the experience and keep you immersed. The entire environment is alive and keeps you guessing and tense.

Game mechanics 7/10 - the game mechanics are a little difficult and some of the interactions can be problematic to figure out, but overall not too complicated and once you're playing and have controls sorted, you're fine. Some of the mechanics get a little repetitive towards the end quarter of the game.

Gameplay and Story 9/10 - very true to the source material, this looks and feels like being part of the cinematic world of Aliens. The story is well written, if slightly predictable in some areas. Some of the back and forth to locate items might be frustrating to some players, but overall a solid story and engrossing gameplay. The environment is well crafted with attention to detail, and nothing is as nerve wracking as crawling through potentially occupied air vents.

Horror 11/10 - Going up against the Xenomorph is horrifying and nerve wracking, the movements and interactions are top tier, this is one of the most iconic horror antagonists and the game does the experience of facing a xenomorph justice.  Facing multiple is terrifying.

Overall highly recommended as an unforgettable experience - this game stands up excellent to the test of time.

148005791.review:
Do not let the fact that this game came out in 2014 deceive you; this game holds up incredibly well in 2023. It is, in my opinion one of the most unique, innovative, and interesting space horror/survival sims out there. The gameplay is deeply involved through use of player devices, item/action animations, and moment-to-moment action; you feel like you are Ripley. 

The crux of the gameplay is of course being hunted by a Xenomorph, which to this day is some of the most interesting and unpredictable AI I have encountered in a horror survival game. Amnesia and Outlast AI is nowhere near the Xenomorph. It is truly something to behold due it's mostly non-scripted hunting and leads to incredibly tense hide and seek gameplay.

The story is again, in my opinion wonderful. Taking place after the first Alien movie, it sticks to Alien lore and only looks to augment an already great IP. From the retro-syfy space setting to overall art direction, this game fits perfectly in the Alien universe. Overall, do not sleep on this game if you are a horror and or space syfy fan!

This game looks great, but the actual gameplay itself is hair pulling infuriating. As someone who is both a fan of the Alien films and the horror game genre, I think what they were able to achieve by capturing the first film's atmosphere is incredible but that all falls flat on it's face when it comes to actual being a "game" and an entertaining enjoyable experience.

I tried so many times to love this game and finally "get it" but sadly I've come to the realization that it just fucking sucks. I understand that this is a stealth game, but the actual stealth aspect itself is absolutely horrendous. You can't move more than 5 feet without being detected, you have to pretty much crouch through the entire game or you're going to get ass blasted every minute or so, even on the lower difficulties. Once you are detected you have to find a locker and sit in there forever as whatever enemy you triggered patrols the area as thoroughly as fucking possible. These motherfuckers inspect every room, every corner, every surface, every crack in the wall and make sure every dust particle is undisturbed before they give up. The sheer amount of bullshit, out of my control moments this game punishes you for is insanity. Whether it's the clunky radial crafting menu UI, the delayed reaction of nearly all weapons, or lower tier enemy AI without any kind of clear patterns or indicators for their behavior. They really should have taken more notes from Outlast, as I fucking love that game and it does everything right. This though, is fucking asinine.

One of the greatest survival horror experiences I think I've ever had. I always come back to this game because not a lot of other games have managed to pull off what this game did. 

This game expertly makes you feel like prey, hiding from a predator, which is one of my favorite horror dynamics. The incredible AI design of the alien gives the impression of sentience, almost like the alien is actually hunting you, and not just poorly thrown together pathfinding.

The game is incredibly optimized and runs extremely well on most devices, and the graphics still hold up to this day. Part of me is sad that this game never saw a sequel, but the other part of me worries that if it did, it wouldn't be anywhere near as good.

147886056.review:
I don't play video games that often and I didn't play them for several years, so I feel like I am perpetually behind on games. I have wanted to play Alien Isolation for a pretty long while and I finally have gotten around to doing that. I'm a huge fan of the Alien movies and so this game always interested me.

I really enjoyed it and it was a great game, very well made, but I don't think I can give it a 10/10 for a couple reasons, though it was a lot of fun and I think it deserves a solid 8 or 8.5 out of 10. 

As a caveat, I don't really play survival games, and this might honestly be the first I've ever played, so keep that in mind.

The Pros:
 - Alien Isolation does a great job of bringing the Alien setting to life. So much of the game is drawn from and inspired from the Alien and Aliens movies and it does a fantastic job of recreating those themes, the art design, the lore, and the general feeling of being vulnerable in space.
- The graphics are really great, even almost ten years later. Everything looks great, straight out of Alien the movie, and the graphics work with the atmosphere to really sell the low-fi futuristic space age. 
- The gameplay is pretty fun, it can be hard at times and I obviously died a lot, but while being challenged, I never felt like things were impossible while playing on the second hardest difficulty (not Nightmare). Crafting system is not super complicated and you don't even really have to use it. I didn't use items other than medpacks for about 95% of the game and in retrospect I might have had an easier time if I did.
- The story is fun, it's straight out of the Alien franchise so while you're not going to get anything world-shatteringly new, it's still a great story with great voice acting.

The Cons:
- Maybe because this was my first survival game, I didn't really know what to expect, but because the AI does different things each time you play for different enemies, I feel like there's a lot of luck in surviving. You do learn some strategies as you play through to deal with different enemies and avoid the alien, but at the same time, many times, if I was having trouble with a particular area, I just had to die enough times and then the alien wouldn't show up, just out of the random spawn point or aggression point or the AI deciding to do a different thing, and I would just advance at that point, without doing anything different, just lucky the alien didn't show up.
- Because of the above point, I didn't really feel like the game was scary and the alien didn't really scare me, it just was mostly frustrating that like I might open the next door and it's standing there, and then I die, and the next time I open the door, it's gone, and I'm fine.
- The middle of the game is a bit of a slog from a story perspective, I would have preferred they cut maybe two or three of the missions, personally, but it's not a huge deal overall.

So, overall, a very fun game and one I enjoyed, I just didn't think it was exactly the masterpiece people said it was. In the future, I have no plans to replay it, I'll just rewatch the movies instead if I want that kind of sci fi engagement. 147811546.review:
Alien: Isolation is the most terrifying game I have played until now and it is unlikely to be dethroned soon.

The game took me about 16 hours to complete, but I replayed it twice to get all achievments.
The games pacing has a dent in the middle of it that pulls the game down a little bit, but soon after it picks up speed again.
Alien: Isolation has phenomenal art design. The space station you are on looks exactly like something you would expect to exist in the Alien universe. It takes heavy inspiration from the first movie especially.
These influences are not only visible in the art design, but also the game play:
You cannot kill the alien. You have to hide and outwit the xenomorph. You get some weapons later on, but they can only scare it away and buy you a short amount of time. Also like the movie the game takes some time to show you the alien. Don't expect to see the xenomorph in the first 2-3 hours of the game.
The alien learns as you play through the campaign. This means if you e.g. hide a lot in lockers it will begin to check them regularly so you have to change your tactic like hide under tables or behind boxes instead. 
You could use noise makers or flares to distract it, but if you do it often enough the alien will begin to ignore them and instead look for where they came from.
The atmosphere in the game is so thick you could cut it with a knive.

Overall I recommend this game to every alien or stealth horror fan out there.

The game is not recommended for people who hate stealth gameplay or unkillable enemies as well as slow and atmospheric openings.

147777548.review:
Simply put, the best horror game I've ever played, and, in my opinion, ever made.

No other horror game has properly scared me, with the environment itself being claustrophobic, decayed, quite creepy, and featuring few jumpscares, but the ones the game does have, are well done, from the environment itself being its own enemy; a station half-decommissioned, with gas vents that can explode scaring the bejeezus out of me, rather than the typical "loud noise and audio-stinger to remind you you're meant to be scared!" antic from other horror games, often those involving haunted houses with pictures that change faces, or some other cheap scare.
On Sevastopol Station, the scares don't feel like they're aimed at you, they're ambient, and you just happened to be there. It's worldbuilding, not just a stinger.

The game is quite replayable, I find, cause even after you've beaten it once, as I did back nearly a decade ago on my old XBOX, I have wanted to play this again on PC for so long. I know the opening few chapters of the game off by heart, and yet, still, I can find myself with the hairs on my neck standing up when I have to try and navigate around the Alien. 
I know the Alien's routines quite well, and you grow used to the audiocues it gives you, but still, it can act quite unpredictably at hand, and, worst of all, it can adapt to your behaviour, and pre-empt your actions if you act predictably.
If you like to wait and hide, it will patrol more. If you are a tunnel rat, it will learn this, and meet you in there, with a friendly grin of its second set of jaws ready to greet you. If you spam the flamethrower, it will come back, quicker, angrier. I really, really hope you learn to economise your gas usage for the flamethrower, you'll need it.

The audio-visual feel of this game is sublime. Hats off to the audio team. Though I've learned the audio-cues for your games, and though I've memorised nearly all of the bleeps and boops of the technology in this game, it's still so charming. And it's a really nice touch to use so many of the sounds from the original films too. Same story with the environmental design and the use of technology; everything looks and feels like the first film, down to the very layout of the first chapter, on-board an M-Class starship, which, the characters note, is "Much like the ship [Ellen Ripley] served on." 

The story is amazingly done, fits neatly into the universe, and feels like a real nightmare on the station. Her daughter, Amanda, is well voice acted for most of the segments of the game, and it makes her quite empathetic in my opinion. She's my favourite playable woman in gaming, if I can claim such a thing. Pragmatic, determined, and driven, even after a life of hardship and grievence; she's developed a wide skill-set in all things technical, and after a steep learning curve, learns to become a survivor, too. The only unlikeable aspect of the story in my opinion is the tutorial section with Axel, who, in his segment, bosses you about and tells you to be quiet about 7 times while you're more quiet than him, and there's some hiccups in the writing on the Torrens, where some of Taylor's delivery doesnt perfectly sync up with the conversation she's meant to be having with Amanda, but then again, it's hard for voice actors' lines to perfectly match the gameplay, as they're often acting months ahead of time for a game that they can't even see in front of them, and this is only a minor gripe, as the lines are just fine.

Did I mention I love this game?
I'll leave it at that.

146605869.review:
This is one of the most boring games I've played.  And the root cause of it is, unfortunately, the xenomorph itself.  The game is designed to be slow, in an attempt to make it more 'strategic' or 'tactical'.  That means even basic things like reloading a weapon require you to hold down a button while your character loads rounds one at a time.  That in itself isn't bad.  The game is paced around that when dealing with human or Working Joe enemies.  However, in order to balance that around the indestructible xenomorph, they made it lumber slowly through hallways, stalking the player like it's Jason Voorhees.  Something no xenomorph in the movies ever did.  They are fast, agile ambush predators.  They hide in vents, they climb walls, they hang from dark ceilings waiting to strike down at unsuspecting prey.  They DON'T walk very slowly through circular hallways while the player hides in a locker.  That wouldn't prevent them from finding you anyway.  Another issue with the game.  Things like a slightly foggy room are enough to make the xenomorph unable to see you from 6 inches away.  Apparently this xenomorph hatched from Mr. Magoo.

If the game used the xenomorph sparingly, used its presence to punctuate tense areas, escapes that made you have to figure out how to distract it, disable pathways, and run to an exit into another area where you lose it for another good portion of the game, when you're then forced to deal with the humans and Working Joes again, it would be a significantly better game.  Instead you get prolonged areas of an hour or more where you're just playing hide and seek with lockers as the xenomorph is always no more than two halls away from you, and you have no way of knowing if it's safe or not to come out of the locker.

The story seems interesting.  I love the main character, Ellen Ripley's daughter who's also a mechanic and thus uses various tools she picks up to open areas of the station bit by bit.  But the overuse of the universe's dumbest xenomorph and the incredibly boring hide-and-seek sections where you spend most of your time staring at the inside of a locker door just kill this game for me.  When Colonial Marines is not only more entertaining, but even with the broken AI has more accurate xenomorphs, then your game is just not worth playing.

Es una aventura tensa que te hará calentarte la cabeza para cualquier tipo de situación. Los materiales van a escasear así que no puedes permitirte ir gastando munición y recursos a lo loco. El juego es largo o al menos se siente muy largo, teniendo una historia interesante y un ambiente muy chulo, lleno de cosas futuristas y cachivaches que te darán una experiencia curiosa: Piratear puertas, detectar enemigos con el radar, cortar cosas con sopletes... ¡Muchas cosas divertidas!

No solo eso. Si te pasas la historia podrás jugar a un modo: El modo Supervivencia. Es una experiencia donde debes hacer misiones personalizadas donde tendrás tus peores y más divertidos retos. 

Los DLC no se quedan cortos... Son trozos de historia que llegan a ser valiosos en cierto punto. Pero eso ya lo descubrís vosotros.

Nada más que decir. Si cabe alguna duda, juégalo... ¡Que no decepciona!

146209873.review:
Alien isolation is a survival horror where you explore and try to survive on a mothership where everything seems to have gone wrong and chaos has consumed all those who are aboard.

The story of alien isolation brings you to a mothership where your mother has seemed to disappear, and you are trying to locate her. The entire ship is in chaos as an alien has been killing crew members and cyborgs has also seemed to turn on humans.

The gameplay consists of mainly stealth and hiding. While you do have an assortment of weapons and tools they are really only useful on human enemies and the basic androids. The alien is immune to damage and will only temporarily flee if you inflict enough damage, but it’s honestly a waste of resources and the only good weapon to thwart the alien is the flame thrower which you get later in the game.

Graphically the game still looks amazing and the voice acting is 10/10 for all those involved. It was truly a great experience story wise and everything was done well.

Let’s discuss some things that really irked me playing the game………

The alien - maybe it’s because I played the game on hard mode but this mofo would not let up, and would be EVERYWHERE you went. There were so many times this thing would come from no where and kill you, even tho the radar gun showed no activity.
I had to replay some parts over and over just because it seems like even stubbing your toe on a soda can would bring the alien down into the ship.

Human enemies - these guys have laser pin point accuracy and will shoot you at some of the most extreme angles. You will die even at full health with 2 bullets. Yes that seems realistic, but god damn they seem to hit you from across then map as you hide behind a vending machine.

The androids - honestly these enemies where funny AF. They would say some funny one liners as you ran for your life because these things would beat you down while asking you if you need assistance lmao.

Honestly if I were to play this game again I would choose an easier mode just to avoid the bs deaths.

Other than that the game was a blast and really kept you engaged. 

I played this on steam deck max settings and it ran at a constant 60fps through the whole game 

8.5/10

146124821.review:
A scathing critique of capitalism is inexplicably rare in mainstream culture. I am not talking about examples like The Outer Worlds or Borderlands, where humour and crudeness is an obvious by-product of the artist's inability to thoroughly conceive a post-capitalist society and the despair this limit on imagination creates. I am not talking about examples like Cameron's Aliens either, where heavy handed use of allegory limits the critique itself to a specific timeframe of capitalist era.

I'm talking about critique like Ridley Scott's Alien and Creative Assembly's Alien: Isolation which are quite unique, where handled material is fundamental to the capitalist society. Both are concerned with space and future on the surface, but you can move both of these stories in any kind of setting where capitalism is the dominant mode of production, and they would still work. The inherent thirst for any kind of "technological leap" that makes the cost insignificant, whether they are human lives or temporary financial setbacks, due to how complete a hegemony over society and politics this leap could provide (think of General Electric, Ford etc.) is a continuous theme throughout capitalist era and the Alien’s presence in that setting only works as a fulcrum to crystalize latent dilemmas of capitalist society.

It is also due to a failed capital venture the Sevastopol is crumbling, the decommissioning work is not up to standards and cost-cutting measures ensured that functionality of the station is extremely limited. This is a regular story in our boring, non-Xenomorph filled world. Think of a not up-to-code highrise collapses and resulting in the death of hundreds (like Grenfell Tower). No one on the space station reacts to Sevastopol’s collapse with sarcastic and dejected humour either, this is their livelihood, and their reactions are blue collar to the bone. This is what makes Alien: Isolation much more palatable than the whole genre of “space as final frontier games”. A dysfunctional elevator can kill you, even if you're not chased by an Alien. If the reason of why the elevator doesn't work is capitalist economic practices, you would not joke about them, you'd get furious.
 
Alien: Isolation is a horrible, terrifying game. Not only because you, the player character, is the favourite delicacy of a relentless stalker, a perfect organism. Lightning does not work half the time, computerised systems are old and prone to malfunction, there are poisonous gas leakages and there is an unreliable AI network. The station is actively trying to kill you and all these factors contribute massively to the faithful recreation of 70's sci-fi, and the horror of original Alien alike. There have been numerous times I was more scared by some other fault of Sevastopol, than the Xenomorph itself. This game made me earnestly think that I'd rather get killed by Alien than be a mechanic of a poorly maintained space station. Especially the first half of the game is unmatched in this sense. While exploring a beautifully crafted 70's sci-fi station, trying not to get too carried by how good it looks, you'll never know the loud thud you heard was another part of the ship falling off, or the Alien dropping off a vent.
 
If anything, Xenomorph serves as a perfect distraction for the corporate suits. In the first half of Alien: Isolation is we witness people who are reduced to their basic survival instincts, forming groups and primarily trying to stay alive. Frontal cortex is suppressed, and only nonethical/tribal reactions are permitted. Only when the Alien threat subsides briefly in the latter half, working-class consciousness surfaces again and some of the inhabitants of Sevastopol, begin to show a clear understanding what this knowledge would mean in a capitalist society. The cost would be dismissible, and executives would not stop pursuing this object of massive technological leap. At that moment, the enemy that needs to be stopped ultimately becomes the capitalists.

Unfortunately, this conceptual elevation in storytelling during the second half does not correspond to gameplay itself. After twelve hours mark, I was scared in every possible way. I knew I was still going to be scared until the game's end, but resignation caused by this idea dropped the tension incredibly low. Creative Assembly discovered the perfect formula to translate Scott’s Alien to gaming medium. Play hide and seek with an opponent you can’t cheat or beat, while malfunctions will leave you frustrated or even serve to take you down if you get overconfident in your abilities, reminding you of your place. 

On a surprisingly related note, I love butter very much, it’s fulfilling, tasty and feels fresh in the mouth. It goes with almost every ingredient you can put in a sandwich. Still “like butter scraped over too much bread”, the game’s ∼19 hour runtime is too much bread for a single ingredient to carry all the weight (not really going to count endlessly repeating 2-3 mini-games) and if the game was compressed to end at around 12th hour mark, its impact would be much more hard-hitting. Without insider knowledge, it is impossible to know if the game was padded to make 60$ singleplayer only, linear game appealing to the masses, as we have been conditioned to evaluate quantity as the primary denominator in the value formula. 
 
Even then, compared to most fifteen or twenty hour mark singleplayer games, Alien: Isolation’s “padding” does not feel like it is there for padding’s sake. If there have been new ingredients in the gameplay formula, I’d have no qualms with it, as only then, the story had hit its full stride. Characters like Samuels and Marlow start to exceed their function as non-interactable story locomotives and revealed the depth of their personality and their viewpoints. Contrastingly, the number of small, scripted events that do much of “show, not tell” heavy lifting for the story also decrease in number in the middle. Brief moments where we witnessed scripted NPCs trying to find their own way through the devastation of Sevastopol was one of my favourite parts of the game, increasing realism that Ripley is not the only one that is at least half sane in this hellhole.

To be honest, if I had written this review right after completing the game, this would have been a much more negative one. If the original movie’s Facehugger is a metaphor for getting a forced face-sitting, this whole game is a metaphor for a plumber porn that frustratingly never moves on from fake fixing stuff part. Nevertheless, after two days of reflecting upon the game, I finally recognized that I loved it and there are many parts of it that I will always carry, like this [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=GSZPxHppXBE]song[/url], or seeing an NPC solemnly sitting, watching the stars, stoically waiting for her inevitable death.

Damn, I made myself emotional now/10

146098786.review:
This is a decent game, but sadly I often found it more annoying than fun. The plot, characters, environments, enemy design, sound design, and music are all solid, but there are major gameplay issues. 

The gameplay has some major problems that drag down the experience. The general controls and exploration gameplay is great. The problems arise when it comes to enemy AI and the gameplay around them. There are three types of enemies in the game with some variation in each category. Humans, Synthetics, and Aliens. The gameplay with the first two types works great. Fighting them is exciting and the stealth mechanics are mostly solid, though I encountered a couple issues with them seeing me through walls or them getting stuck in place. It's a lot of fun getting these two types to fight when you can or luring the Aliens to the humans. The Aliens aren't hostile to synthetics and as far as I can tell there isn't a way to make those two groups fight. It would've been nice if there were a way to provoke conflict between them, but that's not a huge deal.

The real issues are with the Alien gameplay which, unsurprisingly, is at the core of the game. All the Alien enemies can instakill you immediately on contact and there are no QTEs or escape items to save you. That's a very risky approach when it comes to a stealth game. If everything isn't right on point, it can get frustrating very quickly. Sadly, the Alien AI is very buggy and they behave in ways that make no sesne. Multiple times during a single play through I had an Alien glitch through a solid wall or floor and instakill me. I also encountered times when the Alien's tail would clip through objects or walls resulting in the alien catching me even though I wasn't even in the same room. Glitches aside, the Alien AI hovers around you and camps your objectives in a way that makes not sense for the context. Why would the Alien know to camp a specific switch? It doesn't know what the switch does and there's a huge map for it to patrol so why does it just walking in a 5 foot radius around my objective? There are some weapons/items that can scare the Alien away, but supplies can be scarce so it's very annoying to need to waste them scaring off a Alien that's stuck in an AI loop (for example jumping in an out of the same vent dozens of times in a row) or is camping an objective.

These issues are exacerbated by the save system. You can only save at set points and those points are distributed very illogically. Some sections have long sequences with no save points, while overs seem to have a save point every other room. If the devs consistently used one of those approaches, I would think it was intentional but the fact that they flip flop level to level makes me think that it's just poor design from devs that didn't know what they wanted to do.

There are a few levels in the game without the Alien and those levels are excellent. You get to fight the humans and synths and use all the fun weapons you picked up. When the Alien is around using a weapon summons it, so it usually isn't worth the risk of instakill. Which make one wonder why the game gives you all these weapons when they are basically useless for 80% of the game? Eventually, the glitchy, bad AI mess that is the Alien comes back and the game becomes a chore again.

Due to all these issues, the game also dragged terribly and felt far too long. The horror elements are also very weak, so I wouldn't recommend getting it for that aspect. 

Overall, if you like the Alien movies, this game captures them quite well from a visual and audio standpoint. It's just a shame that certain parts of the gameplay are some broken that they drag down the whole experience. I would give this game like a 6/10 for Alien fans, mostly for the visual, audio, and plot elements. If you don't mind dealing with all the jank and resulting frustration, there is some enjoyment there, but know what you're getting into. I recommend only getting it on deep, deep sale.

If you aren't already an Alien fan or a Stealth game fanatic, I would probably pass, since this game is largely a love letter fans of those movies and has many issues weighing it down.

Good: Technically well executed, graphics, atmosphere, sound, attention to details. Sneaking around and confronting enemies is scary and thrilling at first. 

Bad: Shallow, repetitive and unimaginative mission design which mostly consists of pressing buttons to restore power or
activate certain areas, with lots of backtracking. Puzzles are easy, ship lacks distinctive features so it is disorienting to navigate which forces player to spend more time looking at quest arrow and map than actual environments. Can be frustrating. Story is mostly formulaic, predictable and too long.

Conclusion: While I wish more imagination was used in the actual design of missions, enemy encounters and gameplay loop, beautiful technical execution kept me immersed and curious.

Negative:
-Controls a bit clunky, at least on m&kb. Having the item wheel double as the crafting center makes it particularly awkward at times - misclicks abound.
-The human enemy AI is pretty dumb, but you also don't run into them much.

Positive:
-Really good job at capturing the spooky 1979 Alien atmosphere both in graphics and sound.
-The Alien enemy is very well done. Actually pretty stressful to encounter it, especially early-mid game when your only real option is to hide.

Neutral:
-The android enemies are mostly just annoying damage sponges that are a bit overused.
-Story is not very compelling, but not terrible either.
-I'm conflicted on the save stations. Kind of annoying to have to work your way to the next one instead of being able to freely save any time, but the added stress of possibly losing progress is probably a net benefit to the experience.

145799503.review:
Desde el momento en que pisas la estación espacial Sevastopol, sientes el escalofrío recorriendo tu espalda. Los oscuros y claustrofóbicos pasillos te envuelven en una atmósfera de inquietud constante. Cada rincón parece esconder un peligro inminente.

La autenticidad con la que el juego captura el espíritu de las películas "Alien" es asombrosa. Desde la tecnología retrofuturista hasta los ruidos chirriantes de las compuertas, te sentirás como si estuvieras en una película de Ridley Scott.

La estrella del espectáculo, por supuesto, es el Xenomorfo. Nunca antes me  había sentido una presión semejante en un juego. Es implacable, inteligente y mortal. Aprende de tus movimientos y se adapta, manteniendo la tensión en su punto máximo.

Puntos Buenos:

Terror Auténtico: Este juego sabe cómo asustarte. La sensación de estar atrapado en una estación espacial infestada por un Xenomorfo implacable es palpable. Los sustos son genuinos y la tensión nunca se disipa.

Fidelidad a la Franquicia: Los amantes de la película "Alien" encontrarán que el juego capta perfectamente la estética y la atmósfera de la franquicia. Desde la tecnología retrofuturista hasta la música inquietante, se siente como una continuación genuina de la película.

IA Inteligente: El Xenomorfo en el juego utiliza una IA impresionante para rastrearte. Aprende de tus patrones y se adapta, lo que lo convierte en uno de los enemigos más temibles.
Puntos Malos:

Desafiante en Exceso: La dificultad extrema puede resultar frustrante para algunos jugadores. El Xenomorfo puede parecer casi imposible de evadir en momentos, lo que puede llevar a repetir secciones una y otra vez.

Ritmo Lento: El juego tiene un ritmo deliberadamente pausado para construir la tensión, lo que puede no ser del gusto de todos. Algunos jugadores pueden encontrarlo un poco lento en comparación con otros juegos de acción.

Algunos Problemas Técnicos: Aunque en su mayoría está bien pulido, "Alien: Isolation" puede sufrir algunos problemas técnicos menores, como tiempos de carga prolongados o caídas de fotogramas

145346404.review:
Alien Isolation is a great sci-fi horror video game based on the Alien movie franchise, especially the very first Alien movie released way back in 1979.
Speaking of which, I highly recommend you watch that movie first before playing this. While it’s not essential, it will make you appreciate how faithful this game’s atmosphere is to the movie. Also, it’s a great classic.
You play as Amanda Ripley, the daughter of Ellen Ripley, one of the movie protagonists. While searching for clues about her mother's whereabouts, she lands on Sevastopol, a big space station where things aren’t what they seem at first. That’s where the majority of the game takes place.
The big selling point of the game is obviously the Alien and its AI. It’s terrifying and requires you to take a stealthy approach. You can’t kill it, only hide and use distractions. Not only that, but it learns from you, so it becomes more aggressive and counters your strategies if you rely on them too much.
For example, if you hide in lockers a lot, it’ll eventually start checking them before leaving a room, forcing you to rely on different methods to survive. Although sometimes it feels cheap, especially in the beginning where your options are more limited.
You can explore to find resources to craft useful items, and the station even has some Metroidvania elements. However, the longer you explore, the harder it becomes to evade the Alien, especially because there’re no autosaves. You need to reach phone booths and save manually, and they may be a bit apart from each other.
It has a great AI, and you can find a lot of info on the internet explaining it. It’s not scripted and has a lot of interesting elements, like being actually 2 AIs. One of them always knows your position, but only tells the Alien AI the general area you’re in, and the Alien AI is responsible for searching.
However, the Alien isn’t the only threat on the station, and some missions don’t even feature the Alien at all. The other main threat is the station's working androids, that act more like zombies. They’re annoying, but you can actually kill them. They add a bit more variety to the game.
There are also other humans that may be hostile, and even the station itself has some surprises for you. While a bit claustrophobic and repetitive, it’s a character on its own. It has good graphics and lighting, but being mostly enclosed spaces also helps with optimization. The game runs generally well, even on weaker hardware.
My main complaint about the game is that it is long, too long. It sounds weird, and I’m not advocating for shorter games overall, but this one feels too padded. There’s a lot of backtracking and most objectives are similar. There was a point where you might think the game is over after 8-12 hours, but you’re actually only halfway there… I had to play it in shorter sessions because I was getting tired of it, and it just kept on going.
There are also collectibles and achievements that further extend playtime. Not only that, there are also some DLC available, but they’re also optional. They don’t even have achievements associated, so they don’t ruin your overall completion, a small detail I enjoyed.
But yeah, if you’re a fan of horror and/or the Alien franchise, this is a must-buy. It’s one of the best horror games available, even after all these years, and one of the best Alien video games as well since it captures that universe so well.

144954875.review:
Pros:
Very scary and not just the aliens but the androids, too
Simple satisfying gameplay: hide, crawl slowly, use ammo careful, plan via map, trial and error
Atmosphere
Sound
Music
Worthy of the Alien films and lore
Good length
Just enough cinematics

Cons:
- Playtesting some of the levels more would have ironed out some of the confusing sections where it is extremely unclear or tenuously understood by the player where to go
- Game stopping bugs where ID cards don't spawn, leading to endless searches
- Reliance on Youtube walkthroughs to figure out aforementioned issues with tracking to next gate, checkpoint or item

Overall, a superb and thoroughly enjoyable masterpiece in cinematic game design. The claustrophobia, terror and hide-or-die gameplay mechanics catch on quickly for fans of the films. With enough patience, and generous pauses in your play sessions, you can make it through this horror game. The story is satisfying and the gameplay is more than a fulfillment of a film fans dream of being aboard a derelict ship in outer space.

Sidenote: I fantasized about having one chapter where you would be given a huge amount of ammo and weapons to fight off aliens. A short respite from terror. I felt like there was a needed Rambo moment that could have increased the enjoyment in Isolation. It would also give you a chance to breathe in some sanity, before being plunged back into helplessness with a little revolver against a menacing beast.

When I purchased this game for a symbolic one euro some years ago, I had no idea what I was getting myself into. Alien: Isolation is best described as an ongoing anxiety streak—it is stressful and for many, no doubt terrifying. Exactly what one would expect from a good horror game. I had found it surprising at first that despite its quality design, only one out of five Steam players finished the game. However, soon after finishing the first chapters, I understood. The Xenomorph along with all the appallingly soulless androids had me ponder whether I could ever pull through my ordeal. I did, though, and it was cathartic. I felt very accomplished.

Now, unless you get deterred by a lot of—and I really mean *a lot* of  stress, stumbling around and dying, Alien: Isolation is a great option you should consider.

144755182.review:
This is one of the times where I wish that the Steam reviews system were a bit more fine tuned since this game requires a more nuanced take and can't be boiled down to "recommend or not". 

I'm a horror game freak and a huge fan of the original 1979 Alien movie, so when I heard that this game was actually good I was super exicted to play! Unfortunately what I got was not what I was expecting. The game has a really slow start, it takes it's time setting up the Sevastapol and the tone of the game to come, which is welcome. What I didn't find that thrilling is how long the iconic Alien takes to be introduced, which is a down for me personally. 

The thing about this game is that it's simply way too long, it overstays it's welcome HARD, even after what I thought was the last mission of the game there were still almost two hours of gameplay left and by then the horror was already completely gone. The second complain I have is that anything besides the Alien itself is absolutely boring or not scary, the human enemies are really underwhelming and the Working Joes are interesting at first but just become frustrating and a hassle later, having to rely on numbers to be a threat to you. The crafting system is also unnecessary and just slow gameplay down.

Being an Alien game, I also expected the titular Xeno to be in a good chunk of the game but unfortunately, it isn't. The Alien is in basically 50% of the game, which in my opinion simply isn't enough since the entire premise of the game, and fun of it, is being hunted by a smart and deadly predator. 

Now, the game isn't all bad, it's actually quite good whenever you are being chased by the Xeno. It's AI has stood the test of time, and that creates a really tense and creepy experience, where it really feels like you're being hunted by a smart and observant apex predator. The way the AI works also creates really natural and cinematic cenarios since the creature doesn't actually teleport anywhere and has to use the vent system to move around, which increases tensions and makes the sections where they are present just that much cooler.

Overall I think it's a good game, I would recommend it while on sale since I don't think it's worth the full price.

TL;DR: Too little Alien and too much Isolation. 6/10.

Durante nuestro recorrido por Sevastopol nos encontraremos a diferentes tipos de enemigos a parte del ya conocido alien, como grupos de humanos supervivientes con sus propios intereses y algunos fallidos sintéticos con sus propias directrices, pudiendo llevar con nosotros armas con revólveres, lanzallamas y escopetas, además de otros utensilios para poder dar esquinazo al alien, a la par que nos escondemos por taquillas y bajo mesas para poder pasar desapercibidos y proseguir nuestro camino.

144676600.review:
IN SPACE, NO ONE CAN YOU HEAR YOU RAGE QUIT

Unpopular Opinion: Some, if not many, licensed games are absolutely incredible. 

Licensed games evolved during the timespan of the seventh/eighth generation titles. Instead of being marketing tools to promote a movie or TV show, developers lucky enough to get an IP could elaborate on the source material. This was the case with great titles like The Batman Arkham games, Ghostbusters: The Video Game, South Park: The Stick of Truth, and then came Creative Assembly’s survival horror masterwork, Alien Isolation. 

Originally playing it on PS4 back in 2014, I was stunned by the game’s presentation and story. I appreciate the game harkening to the 1979 original as opposed to the more action-packed Aliens 2. The less is more approach elevates the horror. The gameplay is solid, with some dated mapping and menus, but the use of analog terminals and save ports is utter genius. It feels so much like the period of the original film!

Replaying this on the PC has shown that this game has aged really well, still impressing visually and gameplay wise to this day. It’s a port that is well-optimized to the PC with little to no stutter and really smooth gameplay. Since I have a lot of experience with this title, I played this on the nightmare difficulty and holy shiiiiii is it terrifying! Like, I’ve never been so antsy playing a game since playing the nightmare sequences in Max Payne. With equal measure of terror, I also found the difficulty incredibly trying. I hate to admit that I did rage quit time after time but I’m glad to say that I finally completed the game on its hardest difficulty! Overall, incredibly stellar. 

The survival horror genre of video games, or at least the ones I’ve experienced, are defined by an equal mixture of atmosphere and difficulty. Alien: Isolation has this in spades, with great artistic design, tension, and some of the best extreme difficulty gameplay I’ve ever played.

144611820.review:
Fuck this fucking game fuck fuck fuck fuck fuck

This game is arguably, the greatest horror game ever made. Alien Isolation is a direct sequel to Ridley Scott's 1979 scifi horror classic, "Alien," a movie and franchise that I'm sure needs no introduction. Right when you start the game the opening credits displays the 70s 20th Century Fox intro in low analog quality. When SEGA's logo shows up, it's just quiet. No iconic SEGA chimes, the only sound being the hum of an old analog display. Just from that, you can already tell things are not what they seem.

Alien Isolation takes place 15 years after the events of the original 1979 film. You play as Ellen Ripley's daughter Amanda Ripley, an engineer working in the sector her mom disappeared hoping to find answers to what happened to the Nostromo when she's approached by a Wayland-Yutani executive saying they have a possible lead. The Nostromo's flight recorder was recovered on a decommissioned spaceport space station, and you agree to go with them in the hopes it would provide closure. Something's wrong though, as the station's coming apart, the docking clamp is inoperable, and communications are not going through. Ripley and co don spacesuits to make an EVA jump to the station, but an explosion cause you to become separated. Now you're trapped on a space station full of crazed looters, worker androids malfunctioning, and of course...you know...

Which brings me to the star of the game: The Xenomorph. The bulk of the game's development went into the Xenomorph's AI. The Xenomorph does it's own thing, exploring it's new unfamiliar surroundings, but if it so much as catches a hint of you it'll begin investigating. Not just that, but the Xenomorph can be anywhere at anytime. When you think you're safe it could be crawling through the ducts. You could be in a fight with human enemies then the Xenomorph suddenly decides to drop in and join the party. You could be hiding in a locker but made an error and made your hiding spot too obvious and the Xenomorph finds you. You need to study the Xenomorph's unpredictable nature, and adapt to any situation it shows up. Just remember: Nowhere is safe, and if it hears you, you're already dead. Your weapons do not harm it. All you can do is move silently and hide.

Not limited to just the intro, the entire game's art direction follows the same from the movie. Analog lofi computers everywhere, analog data cards, text based command line operating systems on all the computers buttons and knobs everywhere, wood and beige architecture and electronics just like the late 70s. Creative Assembly wanted to make the game as immersive and faithful as possible as if you were directly in the movie.

In terms of technicality, this game is a programming marvel. Feral ported the game not just to macOS (even updating it to 64 bit so Apple Silicon Macs can play it) but they also ported it to Linux and made damn sure it runs beautifully on Steam Deck. Hell they recently ported it to iOS and Android too, because we need to suffer more.

Buy the game. This game is heavily underrated and is the best horror game ever made, but just be warned: it is really really scary. The extreme intelligence of the Xenomorph combined with the lack of a checkpoint system requiring manual saves at save stations adds to the fear as if you die you have to go back to your last save...still trapped with that thing...that could be anywhere...

144505095.review:
Still in the midst of my playthrough, but my GOD am I mad at myself for waiting 9 whole years to give this game its due.

I'm a massive fan of the Alien films (most of them anyway), and there is a LOT to love here. The art direction is incredibly faithful to the films, particularly the first one. The lighting and overall visual quality of this game is actually quite shocking for a 2014 title. It's dated here and there, mostly in things like user interface, character animation, and some minor jank, but graphically? Very much surprised at how it holds up.

The gameplay is solid, aside from the frustration that inevitably comes from playing on harder difficulties and having to replay entire sections because you died before you could reach a save point. The challenge is there for a reason, and the randomness of your encounters with the Alien do wonders to keep the experience fresh and unpredictable. While the human and synthetic AIs are frankly quite pathetic, the alien itself is tuned just right it seems, with a genuine sense of futility every time you encounter it, though not to an extent at which it feels unfair.

It's frankly embarrassing to other studios that in a long line of mediocre attempts of creating an Alien game, the one made by a smaller studio previously only known for RTS games happens to be the best. I am so glad I finally made time to play this.

144446898.review:
Titlu: O Experiență Înspăimântătoare și Autentică în Universul Alien

★★★★★ Recomand

Alien: Isolation aduce la viață atmosfera tensionată și înfricoșătoare a francizei Alien într-un mod captivant și autentic. Cu o grafică impresionantă, mecanici inteligente și o poveste înfricoșătoare, acest joc oferă o experiență de supraviețuire în spațiu de neuitat.

Un aspect notabil al jocului este autenticitatea sa față de universul Alien. Designul navelor și mediilor, sunetele și detaliile adăugă un nivel profund de imersiune într-o lume în care pericolul se ascunde în întuneric. Jocul păstrează fidel estetica și atmosfera caracteristică filmelor originale.

Gameplay-ul se concentrează pe supraviețuire și evitarea amenințărilor. În rolul lui Amanda Ripley, veți trebui să navigați cu grijă prin medii amenințătoare și să vă ascundeți de xenomorph, o creatură mortală și imprevizibilă. Aceasta adaugă o notă de strategie și planificare în abordarea fiecărei situații.

Atmosfera jocului este încărcată de tensiune și înfricoșare. Sunetele înspăimântătoare și lumina scăzută contribuie la crearea unei experiențe în care fiecare pas poate fi ultimul. Această imersiune profundă vă va ține cu siguranță în alertă pe parcursul întregii aventuri.

Un avantaj semnificativ este abordarea neconvențională a AI-ului xenomorph. Creatura este imprevizibilă și vă va urmări într-un mod care simte autentic și terifiant.

Un dezavantaj poate fi că nivelul de dificultate poate fi destul de ridicat în anumite momente, ceea ce poate provoca frustrare pentru unii jucători.

În concluzie, Alien: Isolation este o experiență înspăimântătoare și autentică care capturează esența universului Alien. Cu grafică autentică, gameplay inteligent și atmosferă tensionată, acest joc este o alegere excelentă pentru fanii serialelor de filme Alien și pentru cei care doresc să experimenteze supraviețuirea în fața unui inamic mortal. Indiferent dacă sunteți în căutarea unei experiențe înfricoșătoare sau doriți să explorați un univers captivant și periculos, Alien: Isolation vă va ține în priză și vă va oferi momente de panică și satisfacție.

144221915.review:
[b]Pros:[/b]

[list]
[*]Most beautifully authentic world we've seen in any game in the Alien franchise.
[*]Most dynamic AI in any horror game, if not games in general.
[*]The sound design is impeccable, with a score that compliments the game perfectly.
[*]The challenge. While Crystal Assembly recommends Hard, Nightmare is the way to go in my opinion.
[*]The horror/stealth game-play is a breath of fresh air for the franchise, but you're not completely defenceless, unless you're playing Nightmare... then you're almost defenceless.
[*]There's an overwhelming sense of dread. Alien: Isolation practically oozes suspense.
[*]With a lengthy campaign, five difficulty settings, collectables, achievements, DLC, and Survivor mode, Alien: Isolation definitely has plenty of meat on its bones.
[*]If you like a bit of punishment and the thrill of being scared, have at it. It's a great game.
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]

[list]
[*]The game is somewhat linear, despite the shallow attempts to make it otherwise, and there's a decent amount of backtracking.
[*]Arguably, you can have too much of a good thing. Missions 10 - 14 should have been condensed considerably, with the Working Joes having much less time to... 'shine' (?).
[*]While the console versions of this game are very stable, there's some stability issues with the PC version (surprise, surprise).
[*]If patience is not one of your virtues or you get frustrated easily, I would give the game a miss.
[/list]

[b]Nitpick:[/b] A logic statement allowing players to skip what are essentially interactive cut-scenes after their first play-through would have been nice (happens twice and goes on for about 5 - 10 minutes).

[b]Score:[/b]  I love it. 8/10
