143709392.review:
Let me just start by saying, if you're in the market for a game that makes you question your life choices and the structural integrity of your underwear, then Alien: Isolation is your ticket to a stress-induced wonderland. As someone who thought I had nerves of steel (turns out it's more like aluminium foil), this game provided me with a level of tension that can only be compared to.. well.. I haven't come across anything else this intense yet. 

From the moment you step onto the abandoned space station, your heart will getting quite the workout! The attention to detail in recreating the eerie atmosphere of the Alien universe is astounding. Dark corridors, flickering lights, and an impending sense of doom that's almost cozy once you get used to it. 

The game's protagonist, Amanda Ripley, deserves a round of applause for her dedication to finding her missing mother. She's the kind of person who, instead of running away at the first sign of danger, decides to take a leisurely stroll through alien-infested hallways just to appreciate the architecture. Talk about commitment to sightseeing! And don't even get me started on her ability to find hidey-holes that would make a ninja jealous. If hiding in lockers was an Olympic sport, Amanda would be the undisputed champion. 

Let's not forget the star of the show—the xenomorph itself. It's like playing hide-and-seek with a cat who's had a few too many espressos. One moment it's right behind you, and the next it's vanished into thin air, leaving you questioning if you're dealing with an alien or a magical Houdini cat. And when it does catch up, well, let's just say I've hit notes during those chase scenes that Mariah Carey would envy. 

In conclusion, Alien: Isolation is a masterpiece that brings terror and amusement in equal measures. It's like going on a roller coaster that simultaneously makes you scream and laugh uncontrollably. Just make sure you have a cozy blanket, a pet cat for emotional support, and a spare pair of pants handy. This game is a wild ride that'll have you questioning both your sanity and your ability to survive a space odyssey. 

I'm still waiting for a proper followup to Alien: Isolation and really wish that there was another game like it, it's truly a unique experience that deserves a followup game. I highly recommend playing it!

Oh look, another game I played on my Youtube channel years ago but forgot to review at the time... welp, let's fix that, then. I'll give a link to my Youtube play-through at the end if anyone wants to see a sample of gameplay before buying, but be warned: it's an older series of mine and at the time I had a less-than-beefy PC, so the frame rate of the videos is kind of crap and doesn't really do the game justice. But with that out the way...

Alien Isolation is an excellent sci-fi horror game based on the Alien movie franchise, but be warned: I'd very much describe this game as Type 2 fun. Be ready for one heck of a challenge; one thing the devs excelled at here was the AI of the alien itself. It's unpredictable and it adapts to your play style, so you can never be complacent and think you've got its behaviour completely figured out. As a result, one thing I found is that whenever the alien's around, this game can get stressful very quickly. Hence why I'd call it Type 2 fun, because whilst you're playing you might be freaking out, but afterwards you'll feel triumph at beating the game.

That point aside, Alien Isolation is essentially a sequel to the original Alien movie. You take on the role of Amanda Ripley, daughter of original protagonist Ellen Ripley. After learning that the flight recorder of the Nostromo ship has been recovered, you travel to the Sevastopol space station to take a look - but when you arrive, it's pretty clear that the shizz has already hit the fan there, and law and order have broken down. There's an alien on the loose, there are scattered gangs of surviving humans (some hostile), and furthermore the station's android workforce seems to have gone rogue and is acting under someone else's instructions. Thrust into this, you have to survive and gradually unravel the mystery.

Fans of the original Alien movie will likely love the attention to detail in this game. The general aesthetic is spot on and evocative of the grimy, analog sci-fi design from the original movie, lending the game a fantastic degree of creepy, unsettling atmosphere. In terms of gameplay, there's a huge emphasis on stealth; you'll spend a lot of time sneaking about, hiding in lockers, under desks or in any other nook or cranny you can find, and there are a mix of weapons and craft-able objects (from medkits to a variety of improvised weapons and stealth-aiding equipment). But don't get cocky - there may be weapons but you'll only have limited ammo, and those arms are only really useful for dealing with lesser enemies; the alien itself is far too tough to be harmed by a measly shotgun or revolver!

The sound design is also great, and the voice actors did a good job of conveying the stress and anxiety of the situation on Sevastopol station. Taken altogether, the devs did do a tremendous job with this game.

That's not to say I didn't have one or two minor gripes, though. One source of stress for me was the odd level where save points can be quite dispersed (EG the San Cristobal medical facility area). In essence, there is a manual save system in Alien Isolation; you have to find registration points scattered throughout each level and use these to save your progress. However, you need to take care - enemies can still get you whilst you're saving! And given that certain levels can be a bit sparse when it comes to these save points, it can be very stressful and frustrating if you make one little slip-up, the alien kills you, and then you end up having to redo a load of stuff you previously did successfully.

Also (and this may sound a little contradictory after I praised this earlier) but the alien's AI can itself become a bit of an issue on the odd occasion. What I mean is, the alien's appearances aren't scripted for the most part; it's just always present, wandering about looking for you. The benefit of this is that it lends a huge amount of unpredictability to its behaviour, which really boosts the tension and the scares. The downside to this is that you might find yourself in the odd situation where your progress slows to a crawl, because the alien decides it's going to hang around for ages in that one room you need to enter, forcing you to hide in a locker for 10 minutes until it's AI eventually decides to direct it elsewhere.

But as I said, on the whole those are minor gripes. I'd still say I look back at playing this game and am glad that I did so, for it's a phenomenal game and a very worthy successor to the original Alien movie. I definitely recommend it, just make sure you have a beefy PC that can really do it justice!

Alien Isolation is without a doubt THE Alien experience! I remember playing this game when I was in high school, Scared shitless! More Iconic 80s films should get games just like Alien did, Predator: Hunting Grounds was disappointing but Robocop: Rogue City looks awesome.
The way Isolation recreates the atmosphere and look near identical to the original film was 10/10 alone. Getting a game inbetween the first and second movies is a smart move, but making Ellen's daughter the protagonist was even smarter. Expanding on a character we never see in person in the movies, to giving her a full story about her encounter with the Xenomorph race. The story is very direct and simple, which I love, no crazy twist or plot holes. It is a shame the sequel for this game was a mobile game however. The mobile game was decent for mobile, but a waste and disappointment compared to this. Although unlikely, a true sequel to this game would be amazing. The A.I. of the Alien is incredible, especially for its time of release, not just a dumb animal charging at you, but a intelligent being capable of learning your tactics and finding ways around you. Favourite detail of the Alien for me is the Flamethrower, once you spray it a few times, merely pulling it out without using it is enough to force the Alien to stop and act cautious with you, still slowly approaching but careful to not get burnt.
The music is perfect for the horror the game captures, playing at the right moments and exact times of pressure or intensity. The DLC was honestly perfect! Playing as Ellen herself in this was enough for me, being in the movie itself was a good choice of DLC.
I only hope we get more games like this with Predator or other famous films.
Alien: Isolation is 10/10, I wouldn't see it any other way with the Perfect Organism.

143482883.review:
This game is a love letter to the original Alien movie from 1979. "To help the designers authentically recreate the atmosphere of the film, Fox provided them with 3 terabytes of original production material, including costume photography, concept art, set design, behind the scenes photos, videos, and the film's original sound effect recordings.". And oh man did they use all of that information well. The playthrough is from 10-13 hours (more or less). The level design, lighting and sounds in this game are astonishing. The attention to detail in everything is out of this world (especially for a game from 2014).  The games story is amazing.

You have 3 types of enemies: The alien, humans and androids. All of them require different ways of dealing with.
You have a large arsenal of crafter weapons which you find blueprints and resources to build them, you have weapons like a revolver, shotgun and a flamethrower. 
The alien has only 2 3 scripted places. EVERYTHING ELSE IS AI. Meaning that the Alien might come in the room, search and leave. Or it might circle the room 5 times and then decide to check under the table, in the locker or in the vent that you may be hiding. Theres great youtube videos explaining how the Alien is an AI with a behaviour tree which studies your gamestyle and adapts to it and evolves with time. Difficulty level also affects the behaviour. When i played on easy the alien searched really quick and then canceled the search in seconds and left. On Hard it felt like every 2 steps i take the Alien senses my presence from far far away and is extremely stubborn in his search for me. 

Using your weapons on the Alien won't kill it, it will only make it more furious than before. And when humans shoot at you it will only result in the Alien coming and killing you first and them second (usually). The androids dodge every frontal attack after you have pissed them off. And if you kill the facehuggers, the Alien will come to investigate your sins.

143386477.review:
Alien Isolation is a solid addition to any library. It's a game that knows how to play with its atmosphere, creating a very immersive experience. It has great mechanics, story, and atmosphere. 

The only thing you need to prepare for is patience. 

[h1]First Impressions[/h1]
My first impressions of Alien Isolation were during launch day: 9 years ago. I remember this game being penned as an actual survival horror game using the Alien franchise -- at a time when the last Alien game was the disastrous Aliens: Colonial Marines. 

9 years after launch, I finally gave this game a shot and was delighted to know that those initial impressions rang true. 

Alien Isolation from boot up wants to capture the same feeling of the first Alien movie. On boot up, the game greets you with an old 20th Century Fox logo reminiscent of the Alien movie. Then, the game reveals that its story is set over a decade after the Nostromo incident surrounding a crew looking to discover what happened. 

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Alien Isolation's gameplay is a standard survival horror and stealth. You spend plenty of time hiding and sneaking your way through levels so you don't alert your enemies. Your character, Amanda Ripley, is pretty underpowered with very little means of fighting back. Most of your arsenal consists of distractions and healing. The weapons you do receive have limited uses, and it feels tense whenever you have to use them. 

The game rewards you for taking stealthier approaches while severely punishing you for being careless and noisy. It can be brutal whenever you decide to run through the levels. The enemies will slap you back to the previous save spot. 

This gameplay requires a lot of patience. There are times when you'll have to stay in hiding for minutes at a time because there's an Instakill machine lurking around the corner. It forces you to slow down, breathe, and weigh your options and routes. 

The tension is pretty fun.

[h1]Story[/h1]
In Alien Isolation, you play as Amanda Ripley, daughter of Nostromo's own Ellen Ripley, looking to discover what happened to her mother in the Nostromo Incident from the first Alien movie. 

The story begins with Ripley learning that the Nostromo's flight recorder has been located. As a result, you and a crew travel to Sevastopol Station to retrieve the recorder-- only to find out that the station isn't doing too great. It turns out that retrieving a foreign object from space is uhh... a little dangerous. 

Now you have to survive Sevastopol, discover the root of its problems, and find out about the Nostromo's flight recorder while trying not to be melted by an Alien. 

[h1]Atmosphere[/h1]
This game nails its tense atmosphere. The game's environmental and sound design really shine. It knows when to kill all the noise as it guides you through a quiet corridor for your anxieties to grow -- and then releases the floodgates with levels that activate your fight or flight response. 

The quiet levels could be just you and the echoes of your footsteps, the ominous rumbling of the events, and the hum of the ship. 

The loud levels can be a sensory overload. These levels could include smoke filling a room, alarms BLARING through the speakers, your radar beeping incessantly, and more, all at the same time. 

It is effective, and it is a blast. 

[h1]Final Thoughts[/h1]
Alien Isolation is a great addition to any library. It is a solid survival horror stealth game with great mechanics, story, and atmosphere. 

It is absolutely worth picking up and playing.

143133062.review:
[u][b]"REITERATIVAMENTE REPETITIVO PERO VARIADO EN SU DIVERSIDAD"[/b][/u]. [b]¿Qué?[/b] [b]¿No me expresé bien?[/b] Pero esa es mi más sincera apreciación al terminar laboriosamente esta calamidad que osó recrear la cara de mi amor platónico de hace tres décadas: Sigourney Weaver, con un pésimo CGI que sólo deja entrever la desidia y poca dedicación que tuvieron los encargados del sonido en este videojuego. Sumado a que la protagonista tiene de parecido con su madre lo que yo tengo de diferente con el Xenomorfo. [i](Insertar imagen como evidencia)[/i].

     [b]¿Un viaje lleno de emoción?[/b] Sí, pero más del tipo que te hace segregar fluidos corporales y preguntarte por qué decidiste volver más temprano del colegio aquel día sólo para ver a tus progenitores en plena acción firmando los papeles del divorcio y sentenciando el resto de tu pubertad a un ciclo constante de adicciones, recaídas y, por supuesto, berenjenas al escabeche: todo un deleite culinario que no hizo más que hundirme en mi propia miseria ([b]¿Por qué te fuiste viejita?[/b]). Sin entrar en detalles y volviendo a la cuestión, si buscas un juego donde la tensión y el miedo se apoderen de ti, pregunta en la remisería de enfrente, quizás te orienten en tu búsqueda porque acá no hay nada que se ajuste a dicha descripción ¿[b]O sí[/b]? No, claro que no.

     En primer lugar, hablemos de la trama. [b]¿Una hija en busca de su madre desaparecida en una estación espacial infestada de alienígenas?[/b] Parece buena idea, como aquella vez que le dije que SI a sabiendas de que fácilmente podría hacerse pasar por una de mis hijas, pero [b]¿Quién soy yo para cuestionarme lo que no haya sido cuestionado en su debido momento?[/b]. Sin ahondar en tragedias ya acontecidas y con finales inconclusos [b]¿Quién no ha soñado con recorrer pasillos oscuros y abandonados llenos de criaturas dispuestas a desgarrarte en un abrir y cerrar de ojos?[/b] [b]¡La innovación y los derechos humanos están sobrevalorados![/b]

     Empero no puedo pasar por alto el apartado gráfico. ¡Una obra maestra de baja resolución! Los desarrolladores obviamente decidieron homenajear la estética de los años 90, donde los píxeles y el olor a planta de cáñamo eran el pan de cada día. Es tan encantador ver cómo se tambalean las texturas y cómo el alienígena parece más un recursante de tercer año acechando la última milanesa en toda la casa que una amenaza real. [b]¿Es un monstruo o un modelo recortado de una película de cine erótico de bajo presupuesto?[/b] Nunca lo sabremos con certeza, y no, no puedes revisar mi historial de búsqueda, retrocede, por favor.

     Y hablemos de la jugabilidad. [b]¿Quién necesita un tutorial cuando se invierte 1/3 de la experiencia completa en enseñarte las mecánicas básicas?[/b] ¡La falta de fe que se nos tiene demuestra claramente la decadencia de la juventud en los últimos 10 lustros! Esa sensación de impotencia constante es simplemente reconfortante, [b]¿No crees?[/b] Y qué decir de la inteligencia artificial del alienígena, es como si fuera un candidato político de la fuerza opositora: se pasea por ahí, se acerca sigilosamente, pero, en lugar de atacarte, esgrime sus gemidos cuál promesas de nuevos horizontes, para luego irse a dar un paseo y pensar en su existencia alienígena, como el antagonista de esta obra.

     Los controles, por supuesto, son una maravilla. [b]¿Quién necesita precisión cuando puedes moverte erráticamente y presionar botones al azar mientras el alienígena se acerca sigilosamente para un abrazo inesperado?[/b] Recordándote su penosa programación y pidiéndote, casi suplicando, que cierres el juego y corras a abrazar a cualquiera de tus padres mientras la vida los consume poco reduciendo el tiempo que les queda a tu lado.

     En conclusión, [b]"Alien: Isolation"[/b] es un juego imprescindible si buscas desesperación, confusión y una experiencia técnica y gráfica que te llevará a cuestionar tus elecciones en la vida. Si lo tuyo es el masoquismo digital, [b]¡Adelante![/b] De lo contrario, te recomendaría invertir tu tiempo en algo menos... exasperante.

[b]Nota: Arreglen los puntos de control/10 (¿Quién necesita puntuaciones razonables, de todos modos?)[/b]

It's tragic that the enormous potential of this game was not fulfilled.  The controls are extremely awkward and slow to respond to input and no I don't have a slow PC. Being stalked by the Alien Xenomorph quickly becomes boring. You find yourself creeping around hiding whilst it marches around like an angry parent being forced to participate in a game of hide and seek with a disobedient child.

The game is also buggy as hell. The androids get up to all manner of physics defying shenanigans, which ruins the look of the game. The automatic plot points don't always activate, even after reloading and so I'm then forced to restart a level from scratch.  The game's capricious physics, ham-fisted controls and buggy androids became so extreme in the level where you're trying to access the Apollo core that the game became just too frustrating to play.

It's a damning indictment of an expensive game when someone who's spent the last 30 years playing video games walks away in disgust 85% of the way through the game and watches the end few levels on somebody else's play-through on YouTube.

Just avoid it...I'm sorry to say. What a tragic waste.

I suppose it could've been more accurate on my PC, but I played it in the Steam Deck. I don't usually care for any first person game on console, but this worked. It felt a little clunky, but I kind of like that feeling because the character isn't a Demon slayer, but a common engineer.

This was the most action packed walking simulator I've ever played. The story was great, if not a little challenging to follow at times. Some levels were annoying because it was just back and forth. But they recycled so many maps that it felt like you were really on a space station. They did a good job explaining why you were back tracking when you did as well

142738620.review:
a love letter to the alien franchise, and also the best stealth game of the past 10+ years. I wouldn't really call it a horror game, but it can be stressful. Some really brain challenged people said it was "too long", as if getting 30+ hours out of a purchase is a bad thing. Like, put down the game if you're bored of it, nobody is forcing you to finish it. Just game journalist things, right?

the graphics hold up insanely well for being 9 years old now, though the character models can be goofy at times. The lighting is incredible, the environments look right out of the movie. Overall, one of the best looking games ever made, and on top of that it's performant.

The gameplay is mostly stealth gameplay. Against the alien, you have a type of stealth where staying still makes you die, while at the same time punishing making noise. Against the robots, you have more freedom to make noise and sprint around and even kill them. The game mixes the two together sometimes. 

Overall, if you like stealth games that give you varied enemies and some gadgets to mess around with, you'll like this. If you're an alien fan, you'll like this. If you want an action game where you can run and gun in a power fantasy, you probably won't like it.

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️ (5/5)

Prepare to be immersed in a heart-pounding and spine-chilling survival horror experience with "Alien: Isolation." As a devoted gamer with a penchant for atmospheric storytelling and pulse-pounding gameplay, I can confidently say that this game is a masterpiece that delivers an unparalleled journey of fear and tension.

Set in the haunting and iconic universe of the "Alien" franchise, "Alien: Isolation" casts you as Amanda Ripley, daughter of the renowned Ellen Ripley. Your mission is to unravel the mysteries surrounding the disappearance of your mother and face the relentless and deadly Xenomorph in a desperate bid for survival aboard the isolated and decrepit space station, Sevastopol.

The game's atmosphere is its defining feature. The hauntingly detailed environments, eerie sound design, and masterful use of lighting combine to create an atmosphere of unrelenting dread. The feeling of vulnerability and isolation is palpable, keeping you on edge as you venture deeper into the dark and claustrophobic corridors.

"Alien: Isolation" excels in its approach to stealth and survival gameplay. As you navigate the labyrinthine station, you must rely on stealth and cunning to avoid detection by the cunning Xenomorph, who stalks you relentlessly throughout the game. The Alien's adaptive AI ensures that each encounter is tense and unpredictable, keeping you in a constant state of suspense.

The game's narrative is gripping and expertly weaves into the broader "Alien" lore. Amanda Ripley's quest for truth and survival is enhanced by well-developed characters, compelling audio logs, and environmental storytelling, all of which add depth to the chilling narrative.

The attention to detail in recreating the retro-futuristic aesthetics of the "Alien" universe is commendable. The retro-futuristic technology, reminiscent of the original movie, adds authenticity to the experience and makes you feel like you've stepped into the heart of the iconic sci-fi franchise.

"Alien: Isolation" is a testament to the developers' dedication to crafting an authentic and unforgettable experience. The game's challenging difficulty and emphasis on survival add to its longevity and replayability, ensuring that each playthrough remains gripping and rewarding.

In conclusion, "Alien: Isolation" is a terrifying and atmospheric tour de force in survival horror gaming. Its immersive world, intelligent AI, and heart-pounding gameplay combine to deliver an experience that will keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish.

If you're a fan of the "Alien" franchise or a horror enthusiast seeking an unforgettable and chilling adventure, "Alien: Isolation" is an absolute must-play. Brace yourself for an intense and heart-stopping journey aboard the Sevastopol, where the Xenomorph lurks in the shadows, and survival is the only hope for escape.

142433497.review:
This is a brief NO spoiler review, read if you are questioning if this is for you. 

Ridleys Scott's 1979 Cinematic Masterpiece "Alien" set the standard for space horror that still stands tall to this day. 

Growing up that film shaped my taste in entertainment and holds up to todays standards considerably.

There was something beautiful about the 1970's style futuristic tech that felt grounded in realism, no holograms, no projections, just analog buttons and lights to communicate in the vastness of space. 

This really brought that sense of realism that allowed for Scott to terrify us with a creature that lurks beyond the darkest part of a space ship. Cat and mouse. Never fully understanding what it is that is hunting you.

As a big fan of the first film, I was fairly hesitant to try out Isolation. Truth is, the idea of it was scary as this was heavily painted as a horror title. I myself, am not a big horror video game fan, as I feel developers set out to scare at every corner with jump scares, scripted moments, over the top violence or gore, and linear experiences. 

Well, as of 2023 I got back into the Alien mood and decided it was time to give the game a chance. 

What has unfolded in front of me is an experience I will not soon forget. 

This has fed the craving for more Alien 1979 in more ways than I can name. 

First and foremost, the setting and atmosphere is INCREDIBLE, if you are even remotely a fan of the "setting" of Alien 1979 then this is a love letter to you. The fact that this game came out in the early 2010's is mind blowing as the game plays and looks amazing. 

I mentioned the "analog" scifi aesthetic from the film, well its here, in all of its glory. Buttons, levers, hacking tools, old school dos computers. Its all here. Tangible scifi. The gun shoots bullets, not lasers. Majority of your "tools" are crafted from basic items and look the part. It all fits.

My concern of this game being a "forced" horror title, meaning filled to the brim with shocking moments quickly dissipated. 

Dont get me wrong, this game, well, its scary. Very scary at times.

But this game is scary in a way that YOU have control. If you are killed, its your fault. Its not scripted or forced on you. 

No, its circumstances, its dependent on your play style. And there are different way to accomplish your goals. 

You can go in loud and proud and have to deal with the consequences. Or you can be as silent as a mouse and you will be treated with a stealth experience. Regardless, space is scary, Alien is scary, scary is scary, but its genuinely FUN, and thats the problem I feel with horror titles, is they just tend to be so stressful that they feel like an emotional chore to play. Not here, or at the least, not the entire time.

I have had some laugh out loud moments (circumstantial), nail biting moments, and some overall an experience that will stay with me a long long time. 

So in a brief conclusion for someone who is playing this for the first time in 2023. If you are looking for an atmospheric game in the style of Ridley Scotts masterpiece, there is no game that does it better. 

Dare i say it, 

This is, at least for me, one of the best "games based off of a movie" ever made. 

What ever you do, dont play the DLC before you play the base game, it can be difficult especially if you are not familiar with how the game works. Play the campaign first, it gently gets you used to its control scheme.

So in conclusion, 

In space... no one can hear you scream...

However... my neighbors definitely have...

*motion tracker beep*

142410719.review:
Alien Isolation is a phenomenal game. The only things that I could find even remotely negative is that some things (like selecting/playing terminal recordings) aren't the most clear at first, and some sections just feel drug on (particularly spacesuit sections and all of mission 12). It did not detract from my enjoyment of the game at all though, since after the first couple missions, you can figure out what to do more often than not, and the drug on sections only begin to happen closer to the end of the story.  The game has a wonderful way of luring you to your objective while also building up the alien. 

The alien is incredibly intelligent and aggressive, making it an extremely formidable foe. The other survivors are a nice enemy that pose less and less of a threat as you become more competent and your arsenal increases. Working joes are sturdy and annoying, but they can only melee you, can be outpaced easily, and can be stunned (with some exceptions). The only thing I don't like about them is how they just overpopulate some of the later sections, and from about the halfway point on you see very few hostile survivors. 

Something I find rather refreshing is that the story is simple and explains itself very clearly as the game unfolds. Motivation is relatively simple and most questions and curiosities explain themselves through the main story or through terminals you're likely to read anyway. Too many games in the horror genre, modern ones especially, try to go for super complicated and convoluted mess of lore that's very missable and just somewhat confusing if you don't play the other games in that particular franchise, and causes players to become more fixated on lore than actual horror. Alien Isolation lets the story take a backseat so they can focus on a "show, don't tell" style of horror, unlike modern horror games tendency to tell you about a lot of the horrors that happened in their game.

Overall, I think this game is great for those that want terrifying gameplay, and one of the smartest AI enemies in gaming history, and aren't hoping for a convoluted story.

very good game, atmosphere + the alien itself made for a really good horror experience. 

the alien AI is absolutely amazing and completely steals the show. there hasn't been another game where ive willingly sat in a locker hiding for genuinely like minutes straight because im too shit-scared to get out. i'm never going to forget the sound of the alien's footsteps stomping on the ground.

in conclusion: good game. play it.

142091704.review:
For a game that launched at the turn of the PS3-->PS4 era it still looks and sounds great, the cat & mouse gameplay is still nerve-wracking, and has a satisfying narrative. Even having played the game once before when it came out replaying it this many years later solidifies it as a treasure in gaming history. 

The treasure does have its faults though... Just about anything you interact with (computers, circuit breakers, locking mechanisms, etc) requires a 2-4 second long warm-up animation that you cannot cancel out of which, for a game where an invincible insta-kill alien has a non-zero chance of randomly deciding to grace you with its presence, takes only one instance to turn an otherwise mesmerizing experience into hair-pullingly frustrating. Not sure about you but if an alien dropped from the ceiling ten paces away from me I wouldn't be caught waiting for my computer to completely finish booting up and pre-open steam before I dropped to my knees and crawled under the nearest table.

That said there is something uniquely satisfying sneaking around the few human enemies in the game, and should you make a mistake, get spotted, and they open fire on you, the feeling of silently slinking away into a hideaway while the director AI-controlled alien "OH YEAH"s onto the scene there's few things more hilarious and terrifying at the same time. Coupled with the alien's ability to learn throughout the course of the campaign means you never truly feel safe hiding from it. There's hiding places galore in many scenes, but there's only so many times the alien will hear something sprint into a room down the hall and find nothing behind the tables before it starts checking lockers or under desks. Once or twice it glanced into a room I was in, smirked like nothing was there, left the area through a nearby ceiling vent (successfully baiting me out of my hiding spot) before dropping back through the ceiling a few paces behind. 

It is an A-grade game weather you're a fan of the Alien franchise or never heard of them. I recommend it to anyone for a good horror game. Also keep a notepad handy unless you prefer trying to remember door codes while never completely certain how safe you are.

141961280.review:
If you are a huge fan of the original 1979 as I am, you owe it to yourself to pick up this game. The atmosphere and presentation are ripped straight from the movie, and it only becomes more terrifying as you have to experience it firsthand. Being stalked endlessly by an unstoppable xenomorph is just as stressful as it sounds, and Creative Assembly has nailed the balance between a few scripted encounters and the rest being incredibly unpredictable. I have never had a game leaving me as emotionally and physically drained after a session as this one. The feeling of relief upon getting an achievement that a chapter has been cleared, or reaching the end credits is a uniquely satisfying one.

I have a few minor complaints, but in the face of what this game does right they are incredibly superficial. The game is too long. I finished it in a hair over 13 hours and that was on the quicker end of what I have seen. There is an extended section where the Alien isn't really present, and the androids and human enemies just can't keep up with the intensity of the xenomorph stalking you. If this was instead an enemy-less section where you were lured into a false sense of security about the xenomorph being gone I think it would've been a little more effective.

In short, this is an incredible game that I don't think I ever want to play again.

141709573.review:
First off, Alien Isolation is a fantastic game... when it works.

I'm not talking about optimization here, which btw, is very good. More so the gameplay loop and few visual issues and glitches that pop up from time to time.

Visually, A:I looks fantastic. The entire 1980's "future-past" tech that is featured in the first Alien film is very well recreated here, in every detail possible. Seas of CRT monitors, big chunky buttons and switches, even the iconic "double LCD" calculator watch that Ripley wears. The soundscape is incredible, the whole package really immerses the player. You actually feel like your on a big orbital station (the Sevastopol) and the various ships that you also go onboard throughout the game.

However there are a couple of minor texture issues in the game here and there, sometimes your weapon model "hangs" midair, you can see the Xenomorph T-Pose just before it leaves the rendered map when it enters a vent, and the flamethrower keeps playing the sloshing sound when you reload it until you cycle to another weapon and aim.

The music does set the mood and tone when it plays, although there were a couple times it was either very quiet, to the point where it wasn't adding much, to booming loud, so much so I couldn't hear the log entry I had just found.

Speaking about logs, there are some collectibles to find and achievements to get. In the main campaign at least, all the DLCs are "survivor mode challenge maps" which idc too much about, and a couple maps to recreate the Alien movie in the game. If your a mega-fan, get them, if not, your not missing much if you've seen the movie.

Now, A:I isn't a "Run and Gun" game, and it's one that was anticipated for a long time, since as near as I know, most of not all the other games, official and otherwise, are more focused on the sequel Alien films, which are more about gunning the Xenos down and less about terrified survival. The game does give the player weapons, though I didn't use them too often save the Flamethrower and the Bolt Gun, relying far more on craftables like Molotovs.

 So, how well does A:I pull the survival aspect off?

By enemy type, it depends. First off, you have Human Survivors. The problem is, with how dark the environments can get sometimes, unless if it's *really* obvious, you can't tell right away if a person is just going to passively stand there and repeat a few voice lines (or hide from you), or will start yelling at you and shooting, ofc usually attracting the Xenomorph in the process. When I was in the Mall section of the Solomon Habitation Tower about halfway through the game, a hostile human I didn't initially see started to shoot at me. I responded, and they ducked behind cover. Then someone *very close to, if not basically in the same spot* broke cover and started to run. I shot again and they went down, then the game over screen pops up with "Don't Kill Civilians!".

Oh yeah, like I knew that in the dark Mall while being shot at in the same spot by someone else.

Later on trying to sneak past a Xenomorph and a group of Humans, one spotted me and shotgunned me in the face. (We will come back to AI prioritization in a moment)

Then there are the Androids. The Seegson Working Joes really remind me of the Autons from the classic Dr. Who era. And they are just as unnerving, though usually easy to evade. Taking them out can be a bit of a hassle, especially the Industrial Models encountered later. But the Joes are usually not too big a worry. They won't do anything about a Xenomorph and vice-versa though.

Ofc, the Xenomorph, which thankfully the writers made sure none of the characters or logs refer to it by that name, is a big part of the title. About 80% of the game you are hunted by one, with very few "safe" areas in between.

The Xenomorph is your biggest problem. It will actively stalk the player throughout the campaign, checking rooms, setting up ambushes, and even checking vents and lockers. The devs tried to make the Xeno "learn" and adapt to the player, use too many noisemakers and it will eventually realize they are pointless distractions. Hide in locker after locker and it will eventually figure out where you are. Use your motion tracker too close, and it will hear it. You have to play smart, and when the loop works, it's exhilarating fun. 

When it falls apart a bit, it becomes a tedious annoyance. For reference I played on the "Normal" difficulty, which I do with every game I play for the 1st time.

The Xenomorph's AI has a director function that will tell it not *precisely* where the player is, but the general area. The idea behind this is to keep the player on their toes, and unless a very well placed distraction is pulled off, the Xeno will usually always be nearby. Once it climbs into a vent it's movement is sped up, but it can only travel in straight lines and exit vents. The Xeno can, and often will, "camp" in one room or a set of rooms and hallways, constantly looking for the player. The idea being that you have to time your moment well, otherwise your dead. Very infrequently you can get away with some damage taken as the Xeno barrels past you.

Where it breaks down is when the Xeno keeps cycling between the same 2, 3 or 4 spots in a couple rooms over and over and over, and it feels less natural. I get that it's supposed to be "The Perfect Hunter", but having it rarely go to another area within the level giving the player a small window before returning to the old spot again would have been a better execution imho. Sometimes, the player will get killed just by sheer dumb luck.

Where this section of the game works is by making the player *feel* like they have a chance, no matter how slim. But when the level layout doesn't give many hiding spaces, and the save points are at opposite ends of the level, it feels like the player is being forced to engage the Xeno, which you don't want to do unless as a last resort. One area towards the end of the game really became tedious as after a few deaths, I realized then it was pure chance if the Xeno would pop out of the vent in the next room as soon as I primed the generator or not.

Another issue with the Xeno's AI is it will focus the player something fierce. In the Hospital it kept coming back to the same area I was hiding in a locker, even going so far as to "smell" the locker I was in. The entire time this happened there were a bunch of Humans, a couple of which had just shot at the Xeno, that were running about the Hospital screaming and crying their heads off.

Nope. Gotta focus the player.

So, long story short, come for the story and the visuals, possibly the collectibles as well. And prepare for when the gameplay loop doesn't execute as well as the devs were hoping it would do 24/7.

141604707.review:
Alien: Isolation is an outstanding game that masterfully creates tension, fear, and a constant sense of danger. Set in the universe of the famous Alien film series, it successfully captures the atmosphere and style of the first film. Players can expect stunning graphics, excellent sound design, and challenging gameplay that immerses them in its world from beginning to end.

One of the game's biggest strengths is its emphasis on a realistic approach to survival. As Amanda Ripley, the daughter of the renowned protagonist Ellen Ripley from the first Alien film, you'll be trying to escape the space station Sevastopol, which is infested by the dangerous Xenomorph. You must hide, utilize the environment, and employ cunning to evade the deadly threat that lurks everywhere. This constant tension and fear of encountering the alien is particularly impactful and creates a truly terrifying experience.

The game boasts fantastic visuals with meticulously crafted environmental details that create an authentic atmosphere of the space station. The dark and claustrophobic environments contribute to a sense of uncertainty and tension. The sound design is also excellent, with the sounds of the alien's approaching footsteps and chilling hisses that truly get under your skin. Alien: Isolation truly engulfs players in its world and delivers an unforgettable experience.

The gameplay is demanding yet satisfying. You must make quick and tactical decisions to survive. The use of various tools and gadgets, such as crafting items, is crucial to your chances of success. You must not only avoid the alien but also contend with other dangers, including corrupt humans and androids. Your ability to stay calm and make decisions in high-stress situations will be key to your survival.

141402018.review:
One of the best uses of an intellectual property ever.

They really nailed that lived-in retro-futuristic vibe the original movies had.

The sound design is absolutely spectacular. It captures all the in-universe sounds of the films beautifully. There is also great verisimilitude to the ambient environmental effects and the score is spot on.

Graphics are excellent with perhaps one minor flaw i.e. anti-aliasing at native resolution can be poor. 
However, optimization is excellent for this game so super-sampling and running SMAA Tx2 makes any aliasing, and most temporal shimmering disappear. I use Nvidia 2070 with ML Scaling factors switched on. I set my DSR smoothness to 15% because my native resolution is 1440p. 
I tried the modifications that increase shadow and reflection resolutions but they cause additional flickering and shimmering for me. The game still looks great though with maximum in game settings downsampled from 4K. I switch off a lot of the post effects and think it looks better without them on the pc version, but you may disagree!

Animations range from decent to very good.

UI is functional and integrates the overall aesthetic very nicely.

Gameplay mechanics are pretty tight, and gameplay itself is... tense.  

The game can be quite difficult/frustrating, and it goes on for a long time. Perhaps too long. (Ignore my timed played when reviewed, I played the game on console before)

There are many rewarding moments though and the overall package is excellent, especially with the DLC.

If you're into the Alien movies and their aesthetic, if you're into sci-fi, if you're into survival horror, you'll be into this. 

You spend most of this game alone, vulnerable, lost, and scared witless, but it's also extremely atmospheric, and rewarding when you progress.

You may scream or soil yourself so keep a gag and clean undies nearby if you don't want to upset your housemates. 

Be mindful not to mix up the undies with the gag.

141265262.review:
7th hour - just completed the 5th mission (out of like 20?). I had to find a keycard in a medical facility patrolled by the alien. The medical area is a large circle with locked doors. Unlocking a door opens up another section, and opening another locked door there gives you another large circle with lots of rooms to hide in.

Unfortunately the alien has been programmed to stay near you, or when it wonders too far, return to you. The alien never patrols the areas you leave as you expand its and your access. It's always near. So the whole process is slow while you sneak room to room with your scanner out always looking over your shoulder.

Considering it walked by me multiple times as I hid and it never found anyone in the medical facility (until scripted later), doing circles over and over, you'd think it would give up its search and let me explore freely. It is a game but it kinda broke the immersion for the sake of "now you will just sneak around for hours till you unlock that last door".

The area before the medical facility had patrolling androids to avoid by sneaking around. That was more fun to deal with. More like the gameplay of Dishonored and Hitman that I enjoy. I expect the game has more of all of the above but I've stopped playing. A more forgiving save system may have saved it rather than the specific save points.

I'm a fan of the movies. In the movies people hide and stay still. The alien leaves the area and they can come out of hiding.

141263447.review: Alien: Isolation is a game I have fond memories of. I had played it sometime soon after its release on console, and have just finished a replay of it on PC. This time around I decided to play it on the hardest difficulty to get a new experience. Overall, I feel that Alien: Isolation is a very good game in most regards. In particular, I want to praise the awesome, atmospheric score as well as the faithful, interesting design of the Sevastopol map. The early encounters with the Xenomorphs are extremely tense, and even the space station's "Working Joes" serve as challenging foes at times. The challenge of avoiding, hiding from, or distracting these unkillable alien foes serve as some extremely compelling horror. However, as others have commented, the game is a bit too long for its own good. My run this time around took roughly 19 hours to complete, and especially in the last quarter the game becomes extremely tedious. The addition of the flamethrower/molotovs allow for a way to fight back against the Xenomorphs, however they also allow for certain scripted segments of the game which can be challenging to bypass depending on how you've managed your resources. There was a segment in the last two hours of the game which took me roughly 10-15 retries to complete successfully due to some scripted Xenomorph spawns and limited resources. Furthermore, the pacing of the game (especially in its latter half) could be much improved; as it stands the latter half of the game feels like a series of constant climaxes as opposed to a grand payoff (and the ending as a whole is pretty unsatisfying). Despite these complaints, Alien: Isolation remains a success in creating a tense horror experience within a familiar, yet fleshed out sci-fi setting. I would definitely recommend the game for those who haven't engaged with it.

140638582.review:
I recommend this game only for masochists. It's way too hard even on medium. In the end, it literally requires a walktrough to finish it, and returning to save stations after every action. Which is absurd. I edit my review to "Recommend", only because it's probably very good in its genre and as a story, it's good. And for masochists that replay games until they know each map by heart.  But I personally do not like it. 

I don't like the save stations (sure, it adds intensity, but replaying stuff is really BORING). I did not like the different combinations when you open smt and the absurd cutscenes after each door/hatch open. I didn't not like the alien AI that can get into frenzy mode and chase you EVERYWHERE (I flamed it twice on Mission 10 and it got crazy, finding me literally everywhere and appearing every 15 secs and not being afraid from the flame. I had to decrease to Easy to leave the area. It returned to normal behavior in a level or two). I disliked the way in the first 14 missions, you literally have no time to stop and take a screenshot or just enjoy the station, because you're always running. Not to mention the absurd waiting time and confirmation dialogue when you save. I think devs should realise that Medium level should not feel like waste of hours of your life. Sure, some people like to replay a game until they can finish it in 4 hours but not everyone. For normal people, it should feel like their time is well spent. I didn't feel so. Sure, the game is very immersive and scary and pretty at times. But making it super hard, missing any explanation on the weapons, having to replay scripted events, and re-listen/re-read the logs, that's BORING. It's a waste of time. Also, the game is too long. In the end I just finished it in one day (on Medium), because I didn't want to have to play it anymore.

So yeah, I recommend that people start on Normal/Medium difficulty and if they get super annoyed, just move it to Easy. It's better to save your time and nerves for something more satisfying.

140407868.review:
[h1]Comentario Analítico: "Alien: Isolation"[/h1]

Alien: Isolation lo tiene todo: Es una adaptación fiel a la estética que define a su franquicia, cuenta con escenarios bien realizados en función a la atmósfera de Alien, un arsenal muy versátil, gran atención al detalle y momentos genuinamente interesantes. 

Es el juego soñado para cualquier fan de Alien, pero también es un mal juego de terror.

Comienza prometedor, sabe preparar el ambiente en sus momentos más contemplativos, pero cuando finaliza el acto introductorio es cuando Alien: Isolation empieza a flaquear, encerrándonos con el Xenomorfo una excesiva cantidad de veces y durante una excesiva cantidad de tiempo, haciendo que nos familiaricemos rápidamente con éste y así desmitificando a tanto el antagonista como el entorno.

Y así durante todo el juego, cuyo núcleo es lo mismo que Slenderman persiguiéndonos por el bosque, sólo que con un alien, una nave y más presupuesto. No hay sustancia, el terror es mero jumpscare y la jugabilidad es en esencia la de un mal juego de sigilo con sólo dos o tres opciones para escondernos.

Es una pena, porque casi todo lo demás acá es excelente (Menos las expresiones faciales), pero la parte más importante es la más descuidada.

[b]¿En conclusión?[/b] No lo recomiendo.

140237293.review:
Alien: Isolation was a very mixed experience for me. For the first half it is a really solid game that keeps you on your toes and tense. However, after Mission 10 the game takes a huge dip for about 3 missions before returning back to what made the first half great.

What I liked most about Alien: Isolation was the presentation. The creators 100% nailed the retro-futuristic look of the original film with blocky computers and very little tech. I also enjoyed the star of the game, the Alien. Never before has a enemy in a horror game made me so tense, as the Alien is invincible and kills the character instantly. However, after playing for a while, the AI is easily exploitable and you have enough tools to deal with it.

Some things that brought the experience down for me was the lack of said Alien. This was mostly my fault though since I did a full playthrough on Normal and a quick speedrun on Hard for the last achievement so I didn't have to play the whole game again. If you want to get the full experience, play on Hard. The game could also have been cut just a little bit due to 3 missions being redundant in the end.

Overall, Alien: Isolation is a terrifying game that has it's highs and lows but will leave you shaking in your seat.

7/10

140224973.review:
Alien Isolation is  a sci fi survival horror game that uses the xenomorph from the first alien film as the main enemy along with some hostile human enemies and androids to add a bit of variety. It also makes the first films events  a prequel to to this games story where they are kind of linked together. You play as Amanda Ripley  who is Ellen Ripleys non cannon daughter who is in a crew that belongs to a ship called The Torrens. If you are a fan or the Alien film esp the first one and like the sci fi survival horror genre I recommend this game to you. You should play it.

Story: 9/10
Without spoiling anything they did a good job with using the first movie's story as inspiration and as a prequel to this game. It flows on nicely into this games story. There is a lot of nice twists and turns that keep the story interesting as well. The characters and dialogue is well done except for maybe like the pilot and captain of the Torrens cause they don't really do or say much story wise. The main character that you play as is interesting. Unfortunately though the characters from the Alien movie aren't in this game. They are only referenced through audio recordings. There is a separate campaign DLC you can get where you play as Ripley or one of her crew members on the Nostromo. This game is quite long as well with 19 Chapters. Some chapters are long and others are short overall it is a good length and plenty of  stuff happens in them.

Sound/Music: 9/10
The sound choices are really good and realistic almost like the movie.  They fit really well for a survival horror game. You hear a lot of different noises in this game and some are some are good indicators towards danger like heavy ground footsteps or ventilation shaft footsteps. The alien sounds are very good and keep you  aware and cautious in game. Weapons and item sounds are good and pretty loud and iconic in this game as well. As for music there is what you would expect for a survival horror  game. Some suspenseful tracks and some eerie tracks but mostly a lot of silence which helps for the scary and dark atmosphere of the game.

Gameplay: 9/10
The gameplay is pretty good and balanced for a survival horror game. You have  to scavenge and look around for weapons and ammo.  You don't get a lot of guns and they are not super powerful either. The two best guns are the iconic flamethrower to scare the alien with, and a new gun called the bolt gun which is useful against the andoids. in this game and the alien can't be killed by them only scared away temporarily which is a nice change I like. It helps keep the fear factor going and the suspense cause you never know when he will come back.  There is also blueprints  for items like medkits, molotovs and smoke bombs  you can craft  lying around as well as crafting components. They are all useful.  You get the motion tracker in  this game as well which is nice and it works pretty well for detecting  enemies that are not too far away from you. The enemy A.I is pretty smart and challenging esp the Alien so long as you don't put the the difficulty to low. Recommended is hard difficulty on first playthrough by the developers for the best experience. It makes you think how to approach each situation and encounter . A lot of the time you will have to hide and be patient esp early on. There is a lot more emphasis on the survival aspect in this game esp on the harder difficulties. You can't  be wasteful with ammo or crafting items cause you don't get a huge amount and it is really easy to die in this game. Also this game uses save stations instead of manual save system where you can save anywhere which I think is probably better for this game as it adds another layer of difficulty and suspense. They are not too far apart and can be used  multiple times as well. 

Overall Score: 9/10
This game is a must get if you like and have the patience for this type of survival horror game and you are a fan of the first Alien film. It is not a action shooter horror game like Dead Space or Resident Evil but if you give it time and have patience it will grow on you.

140097744.review:
Alien: Isolation offers an oppressive, suspenseful horror experience that gives you a true sense of helplessness when facing the Xenomorph; as you can do nothing but hide and pray that you don't get caught, even with an impressive arsenal of weapons at your disposal.

However, the game becomes much easier as you get more materials and ammo, and if you've done well in conserving your resources in the early game, the endgame becomes pretty trivial. The Xenomorph runs away when you use molotovs and the flamethrower, and since the game pretty much keeps you stocked up even in Hard difficulty (if you avoid most encounters and conserve your ammo), the last few missions feel more like a nuisance to play through, rather than being scary.

Still, I have to hand it to the developers, the game still looks great after all these years and offers a great horror experience for the most part. Plus, Sevastopol is interesting to explore and I like the fact that you slowly begin to find out how the alien got aboard the station and get to see where it all started as well.

Also, fuck those Working Joe Synth bastards. They can suck Xenomorph cock for all I care. I literally stopped playing three times because of the Seegson Communications mission. I cannot express how satisfying it was to take those PIECES OF JUNK out in the endgame, god bless the bolt gun.

139604430.review:
i review games on steam after i 100% complete them! check out my reviews to see all the games i have completed!

alien: isolation is a first-person stealth horror game developed by british video game developer creative assembly and published by sega. in march 2005, creative assembly was acquired by sega and became a part of their european branch. the game released in october 2014 for PC, PS3/PS4, xbox 360, and xbox one, while it was later ported to the nintendo switch in 2019 and iOS/android devices in 2021. it's based on the alien film series and is set 15 years after the events of the original 1979 film. you also play as the daughter of the protagonist from the original movie as well, investigating the disappearance of your mother. 

the alien project started out small, but eventually grew to a group over 100 people working at creative assembly, after previously just being "crammed in with the total war guys" (creative assembly is/was best known for their games in the total war series). sega acquired the rights to develop games using the alien franchise in 2006, just a  year after they acquired creative assembly. they decided to model the game more with ridley scott's original 1979 film "alien" as opposed to the more action-oriented sequel "aliens" directed by james cameron in 1986.

alien: isolation is a genuinely good horror game, and a very effective adaptation of a classic film. all of the mechanics work together to make a unique and horrifying experience. the visuals are beautiful, with tons of shadows throughout the setting. the aesthetic is that of a lo-fi 70s vision of what the future would've looked like, with futuristic CRT TVs and old-school phone receivers. An artist even revealed they had a in-house rule that if an item/prop couldn't have been made/done in 1979 then they weren't allowed to use it in the game. the art design sets alien: isolation apart from the likes of a system shock or dead space by creating a legitimately convincing sci-fi world with machines and environments that are unique and still realistic-looking, rather than overtly futuristic. for a a game that is almost ten years old as of the time of writing this review (june 2023), i was definitely impressed with the visuals, especially as I am playing a lot of games from this era right about now as i work through my steam backlog. 

the characters, however, are all mostly forgettable. we never really spend enough time for deaths to ever mean anything significant, and a lot of the added lore/plot/narrative that is delivered through "logs" are uninspired, at least to me, which is sad because i normally eat these kinds of things up with no complaints in almost any circumstance. the alien itself has extremely good AI and the gameplay is fun, even as someone who normally hates playing through horror games. it can be repetitive but luckily doesn't drag on for too long and the biggest complaint was hiding for way too long just waiting for an opening to leave. 

overall, this is a amazing game that delivered on a lot of aspects and really impressed me. i can only imagine how people felt who played this for the first time in 2014 or shortly thereafter as this probably was a mind-blowing experience. while full price for this was lowered to $40 from $50 in july 2016, you can routinely find this for 80% off during sales, making it only $8 for what is maybe the best horror game of all time. definitely in my top-3, probably currently tied for #1 with outlast. i'm definitely looking forward to getting to other horror games in the future, as i think outlast and now this game have kind of made them all a bit more accessible to me. while you wouldn't be overpaying if you bought at full price, i definitely recommend waiting for a sale and grabbing this.

Tried once and got to spooked before I even was in an area where the Alien was even active.  A friend got it on sale and we played through it together simultaneously, man did I miss out.  Lots of fun to go through if even if you are not too familiar with the Alien movies.  

A lot a people have said the game drags on causing the scariness to go away, I feel the length was just fine overall.  If anything (excluding occasional set "jump-scares" of something breaking, side note facehuggers are the worst thing every created) I felt once I encountered the Alien once, the fear went away.  The moments you are being hunted are tense for sure but I never truly felt scared of him after I got killed by him a few times  which is fine for me.  You tend to know he is coming for you long in advance given you plenty of cues to know you are about to die.

There were a few glitches I ran into, none of which were game breaking.  Firstly the game needs to be locked via your graphics card control panel to 60FPS or else you will get no sound effects on the death screens.  Secondly there were a few visual glitches of floating guns (one which made a person unable to attack me) and I was permanently on fire for the last 5 mins of the game while taking no damage.

Overall I would give this game an 8.5/10.

Final point: The Alien is an adorable friend that just wants to give you a friendly Nomp.

139216354.review:
I have had this game in my library for years, and never completed it, but going through a "clean up old library" phase right now and gave it ago.

I will say, I do recommend this game - but it's not for everyone.

Pros:
-Great Visuals: This came out in 2014 and with a simple reshade this game looked like a current gen game (mostly)
-Great Sound: The sound design is this game is pretty incredible lots of great sound cues and atmospheric sounds. There are a few glitches in sound sometimes, though.
-Decent Story: The story it nothing to write home about, it's just basic fair..but it's not complete garbage and doesn't detract from the game.
-Gameplay: Cool mix of puzzles/minigames (super easy though), stealth/some FPS combat and exploration.
-Length: If you want a long game, this one is pretty long (however, I'll mention this again in negatives)
-Cool Gadgets: Lots of cool weapons and gadgets, although you might find yourself barely using most of them.

Cons:
-Alien AI: The AI is touted as top notch, however the Alien AI is quite garbage. The alien will teleport around the map and sometimes get you in the middle of events and stuff where you have no chance to get away. Since the game uses a checkpoint style save system, you will end up repeating a lot of sections, which is annoying, and wears on you over time. If you're going for 100%,then this will REALLY be a problem. You'll be forced to play on Easy and quickly reload saves when you undoubtedly get caught by the alien.
-Repetitive: The game is awesome, but over time some will get bored and just want the game to end.
-Length: This goes with the above, but due to the length of the game you will eventually start to get bored and tired with the game. This might be a problem for some, and not a problem for others.

Overall, I really enjoyed this game, and it is definitely one of the best Aliens games ever created. Even in 2023, I really enjoyed this play through and feel like it's a must play for any Aliens fans (and maybe even some that are not fans of the Aliens franchise).

139213681.review:
[h1]An Unforgettable Nightmare in the Alien franchise.[/h1]

As a fan of the horror genre and a lover of intense gaming experiences, "Alien: Isolation" exceeded my expectations in delivering a truly terrifying and heart-pounding encounter with the iconic Xenomorph. Developed by Creative Assembly, this survival horror game immersed me in the haunting atmosphere of the Alien franchise.

Pros: [list]
[*]The fear factor in "Alien: Isolation" is unparalleled, especially when crawling through the vents while the Xenomorph hunts you. The constant tension and fear of being discovered kept me on the edge of my seat.

[*]The first encounter with the Xenomorph is a spine-chilling moment that leaves a lasting impact. The creature's design and behaviour are incredibly menacing and realistic, enhancing the fear factor.

[*]The game's atmospheric and detailed environments, set aboard a derelict space station, effectively conveyed a sense of isolation and dread, contributing to the overall immersion.

[*]The sound design deserves praise, with creaking metal, distant screams, and the Xenomorph's eerie screeches creating an unsettling ambience.
[/list]
Cons:
[list]
[*]While the fear factor is a major strength, it can also be overwhelming for some players, making it difficult to progress or even causing excessive stress.

[*]The game's save system, relying solely on manual save points, can be frustrating, as a single mistake or death can result in significant progress loss.

[*]The game's pacing can feel slow at times, with lengthy periods of exploration and stealth game play, which may not suit players seeking constant action.
[/list]

In conclusion, "Alien: Isolation" offers a terrifying and unforgettable horror experience, successfully capturing the fear of being pursued by the Xenomorph. Despite some potential drawbacks, the game's unparalleled fear factor, atmospheric environments, and immersive sound design make it a must-play for fans of the genre, providing an intense and memorable journey.

139114256.review:
|REC Review|

Alien Isolation is one of those games that can be considered gritty and scary but at the same time as thrilling as it is beautiful. With very high quality graphics for its time and a well structured Gameplay, Alien Isolation really manages to put the player into an adventure of pure terror and anxiety, making it as alive as in the famous Movies. Engaging storyline and spectacular animations, good weapon combos and remarkable AI in many cases, maybe a bit repetitive with the missions as you go along but that's very little if we compare the rest.

Pros:
-Really well done graphics, animations and voice acting for the time of release of this game
-Interesting gameplay, especially with the use of the Controller; excellent combos with weapons and good freedom of movement
-Compelling and interesting story, manages to immerse you in the plot
- Remarkable AI, quite smart and fast in many cases
-100% perfect terror effect, with the use of background sounds and cinematic effects

Against:
-It has, not always, a certain amount of bugs or defects. It could happen that, for those who do not have a powerful computer, sudden exits or slowness in the FPS occur
-Good storyline, but repetitive with unnecessarily boring missions and moments
-AI remarkable, but not perfect. Often slow to understand certain things or simply interact with them

Conclusions:
For those looking for a scary but exciting adventure, which can enhance the surprise effect at any time and with the addition of many references to the original Films, Alien Isolation is definitely for you

Rating: 7,5/10

I kinda have a love hate relationship with this game. I played it first and platinum it on PS4 initially, few years later I thought I would buy the game again on PC as it was on sale and I quite enjoy the game as a fan of the Alien franchise. However.... upon revisiting the game on PC I remembered how much of a chore and bore the first few hours of the game was, it's not until you get the flamethrower that things starts to get a little more interesting and the story starts to move forward. I was only able to power through the first few hours and finish the game because I'm a Alien fan and a completionist, but to those that aren't ..... well...

I can see why a lot of people that aren't Alien fans drop the game after the first few hours, i myself included dropped the game on PC until almost a year later i decided to get back into the game to 100% it. This game is one of those games that doesn't offer much replay value in terms of the main campaign, its really hard to recommend this game to anyone that doesn't have much or any interest in the Alien franchise as to them its just a glorified hide and seek game. To those that are fond of the franchise and are looking to explore and dive deep into the lore of the Alien universe I'd say this is the best game to experience it. 

I love that the game offers and expands the lore but also able to exist in its own bubble outside of the movies but the gameplay and story is kinda stale in the beginning. Other than that, this game is a tough sell to anyone that has no interest in the Alien Universe and why IGN gave this game a 5.9 / 10 rating. Also, Fxxk you IGN you robbed us fans of a sequal to this gem of a game.

138607767.review:
In a world where games come out as uncompleted hot piles of garbage, its shocking when this game is not only graphically advanced, it is also heavily optimized so a crap laptop like mine can enjoy it too with surprisingly great graphics. 

Story is immersive in the Alien Universe, everything is thought out and you can see how people made specific technologies in line with this alternative universe. For example, space travel is possible, yet computers are still analog. 

The one complaint I do have about the game is that making this game harder does not make the game more of a challenge. It just makes it annoying. Setting the difficulty up a level does not make the alien's AI more advanced, it just makes it more persistent and bullsh*tty. Instead of a scary, cunning monster, you can tell it's a coded entity that sometimes makes the gameplay unnecessarily more effortful. Raising the difficulty makes you notice the flaws of the Alien creature more.

Beat it on hard, wanting a challenge, but all I felt was I learned how to navigate around a glitchy, predictable AI.

Also, I get how, in theory, making you start at your last save station makes you more careful and effortful on how you play, since all your progress up to that point will be lost when you die, but it ended up being more of a nuisance. They should have just implemented automatic quick saves. I knew when to stop playing for the day when I got annoyed at having to repeat the same part over and over again, not because of a difficult alien, but because of a glitchy one that made the area nigh impossible to clear.

138581956.review: W horror game. Not so scary you can't play but gives you the chills

138545667.review:
I just finished my first playthrough on nightmare mode. I really wanted a challenge and thought the nightmare mode would be the scariest, however that isn't really the case. I regret playing the game on nightmare mode (as a FIRST playthrough) cause I think it kinda ruined the game for me. I didn't know anything about the map, the enemies, the allies, the missions, the lore so I died a *lot* of times. I feel like this really killed the horror for me and it was more sneaking, playing immersive and smart and camping under a table for 5 minutes straight every 2 minutes. In the end the nightmare mode isnt very scary (cause you die a lot of times and you get used to the enemies killing you and chasing you) but very hard. Items/ ammo/ weapons/ loot is EXTREMELY limited, I think it is save to say out of probably 150 item boxes and dead bodies I looted I only found 5x something. I didn't use any ammo nor Items until mission 10 and even then I barely had anything before. I do have to say I liked this aspect of the nightmare mode as I prefer harder challenges anyways and it really pushed me to my limits to play smart rather to run everyone and everything down with the shotgun. I just disliked how if you killed humans with pistols that you couldnt loot their ammo/ weapon (cause on nightmare you almost never find anything with looting), this is the only part I disliked and it really made little sense to me.
I really liked that on nightmare mode the motion sensor is broken (to a certain degree), which does add some thrill to it. The motion sensor sadly wasn't 100% accurate always, I did die a few times to enemies not being picked up by the motion sensor even tho they were walking (The motion sensor does not pick up enemies which stand still which is good and fair). I don't know if thats part of the nightmare mode, I would have to replay the game on a different difficulty to see the difference.
Also one time the alien was in the vents behind me and when I opened the door it suddenly spawned in front of me, which very clearly was just a bug. Annoying if you go for a 0 deaths playthrough (which obviously I didn't). However this only happened once and besides that the aliens movement was very accurate and good. I really liked that after some time the alien even started sniffing around and found you hiding behind tables and chairs, this is something the aliens started doing to me at the end of the game so the alien intelligence really adapts to your movement. 
I thought not having a map would be my biggest struggle as I have terrible sense of direction however the missions were in most instances very clear were you have to go and despite my orientation struggle I usually found my way through the building rather quickly. I really liked that you don't have a map on nightmare mode, it is more realistic and more thrilling.
There were some sound bugs after dying which were easily fixable (pulling out your weapon usually helped) except for one time where the audio logs were super slowed and deep voices and they wouldnt stop after finishing the audio log. I had to die to make it stop. Besides that bugs were usually minor and definetely nothing which breaks the game. I did find it funny that there is one passcode which you cannot use in the game cause the developers most likely forgot about it. I was stressing out when I finally get to use it .. well never :D 

Despite wishing I didn't do my first playthrough ever on the hardest gamemode, I do have to say this is my mistake and from an objective perspective I really enjoyed the game. I love immersive, stealth games in general and enjoyed having to go around enemies, sneak past them to get some clues or items/ objectives needed. I just wish that the horror aspect wasn't killed for me from dying so often but as being said this is my fault.
I would say the game is rather survival than horror (on nightmare mode at least) which is also fine by me. The atmosphere was always amazing and I LOVED the music/ soundtracks being played. I do think 3x the music was misplaced ("chasing" music when nothing and no one was chasing me) but besides that I really loved the instrumental approach this game offers. 
The map layout is HUGE and you can clearly tell how much planning, structuring and design was put into this game. I loved the entire station and think it was beautifully designed. I loved going past the big windows being able to see outside (especially when events happened outside). I also loved the outer space walks towards the end of the game, the atmosphere was unbelievable good and I felt very euphoric being outside in the space. I also enjoyed the inverted mission where you play as Marlow on another planet.

In the end I can definetely say this is one of the best games I played and I will play it on another difficulty to go for my 50 achievements (I got 45 achievements out of 48 possible in the first run, which did make me a little proud :)). I am sure I will enjoy it just like I did the first time and maybe this time on an easier difficulty + knowing the enemies, their movement and the map the horror atmosphere might come back for me. I will also play the DLCs to see what they have to offer so this review is solely on my first playthrough from the main story.
I can 100% recommend this game, and I cannot wait for another alien/ space game which comes close to this game from an artistic approach (scenes, layout, music).

138254525.review:
Probably my favourite horror game. Admittedly I don't play many, so for me to play one at all is an achievement. 

Alien Isolation is a fantastic homage to the original Alien movie and it's concepts. Every little detail, from the curved crt monitors to the clean hexagonal corridors has been recreated to such a high degree that it feels like being in the movie. The way the game is focused more on escaping and hiding from dangers rather than confronting them adds to your feeling of vulnerability, and really takes this game from solely being a tense space game to a full on horror one. 

I attempted to play it years ago, but stopped after meeting the Xenomorph face to face for the first time. It just had such a ridiculous presence and force on the player that the dread became palpable. It was only recently I managed to push through and complete the game, and thank god I did. From the moment you meet the Alien right through to the end of the game, you NEVER feel safe. And by the end, you'll feel somewhat proud of the fact that you managed to make it through to the end. It's a weird sense of achievement that I assume only a seriously good horror game can provide. 

If you're even remotely interested in the Alien franchise you HAVE to pick this up. The accuracy to the source material hasn't been beaten by anything else before or since and it just oozes "passion project" from every seam.
