Great survival horror game! Playing this now 8 years later, as it was too stressful/scary for me the last time (playing on Hard, in which the menu tip states "how it's was meant to be played").

The environmental design is incredibly well done (all in good 70's sci-fi with extreme attention to detail), the sound-design is absolutely amazing, and the general level of immersion is beyond anything I've tried earlier (it is probably due to the aforementioned merits in combination with some X-factor in the camera movement, intricate interaction animations and butter smooth performance.

And off course the Xenomorph hunting you is such a brilliant nightmare that it's causing tension even to those parts of the game it's not on your heels.  Though it CAN be frustrating at times as the inherent randomness of the Xenomorhp's movement can take you out on sheer bad luck, and sometimes leave you off the hook altoghether. But that's ok.

The AI is insane, and I appreciate that it is not all run-and-hide like Outlast and other horror games where you can only hide, and have no way to defend yourself or switch up strategies. You get access to weapons and tools, and even a crafting system. The best part of the game is the incredible accuracy and detail the creators achieved in recapturing the feel, look and sound of the original 1970's film. The sound effects, lighting, color palette and ambiance are identical to the movie. I definitely recommend this game. 10/10

137572728.review:
It's a wonderful experience from start to finish. 

It can be quite challenging, especially near the very end of the story, but it's also not unfair, unless you're playing on Nightmare difficulty. The AI is pretty terrifying and will almost always have you on your toes. There are a few times that you can abuse the AI, but otherwise it's pretty smart.

Everything else from the visual and sound design to the story and characters are handled extremely well in my opinion.

By far one of my favorite horror game experiences, and well worth the price. I'm usually not one for gore and blood, but this strikes a balance that I can quite easily handle. I'd be more than willing to have a sequel to this masterpiece. If you like horror or see the game on sale, it is a must play.

And as for the best character? Ricardo. I don't need to explain.

Edit: I forgot to mention this is one of the few games I was able to get all the achievements on. They can be difficult, but not as unfair as beating the game without saving (looking at you, Resident Evil 0).

137342151.review:
The best Alien game. While other products in the franchise mainly focus on the trigger-happy feeling of overpowering xenomorphs and killing them as a team (fun to some, boring to others), this game provides the intended feeling you should get when coming face-to-face with a xenomorph; pure terror. The alien is quite possibly the best unstoppable killer in any video game, everything from its model design down to the ingenious AI dead-set on finding you could not be more perfect.

The aesthetic is ripped beautifully from the first movie in 1979, essentially 'how we thought space stations would look like back then', meaning there are plenty of claustrophobically tight spaces that make you feel truly trapped on Sevastopol, as well as outdated technology doomed to fail at almost every turn during your escape. And then of course, the occasional banging in the vents above, a reminder of the looming threat that will pursue you no matter how much you're armed. You're by yourself, but not alone.

There have been, and still will be many games that try to replicate the sense of despair Alien: Isolation brings to newcomers on their first playthrough, but I believe there will truly be no other game quite like it. Lightning in a bottle that holds up almost 10 years later.

137331897.review: I don't know if there's a point to write review for a such old game, its nearly a 10 years passed since it was released, and I honestly can say that it's still one of the best survival horror ever created. Not many games can create such an eerie atmosphere where you feel constant fear for a whole game, one mistake and you are basically dead. In this game you are the prey, and the hunter is deadly efficient. Play on hard mode to get the best experience, only on hard difficulty (recommended by devs) Alien AI is working like it was programmed. It was the pleasure to play through it again after some years

137297644.review:
The world is immersive. The early moments of this game are so wonderfully evocative of the retrofuturism of the Alien franchise to be almost worth the discounted price for which I purchased this game.

Unfortunately, once the gameplay starts in earnest, you won't have time to immerse yourself in the world, as it seems you will spend the whole game sitting under a desk or in a closet or vent, leaning your face on your elbow, waiting for a big spoopy alien to walk away -only to instead watch it pace back and forth in front of you for several minutes at a time. And don't you dare get impatient, for the save states are few and far between, meaning one hasty pinky extended outside the safety of that gum-encrusted desk space before the alien is good and ready to let you go means you'll be set back half an hour of riveting "watch paint drying" action

Perhaps if you're the kind of gamer that finds the musical sting of a jump-scare to be all you need to feel engaged, this will be the game for you.
Otherwise, there is no fear in this game, only dread. The dull, exasperating dread of having to replay tedious sections of a game that really ought to be better than this

137150814.review:
really really loved this game! beautiful atmosphere and design that's true to Alien (1979). I am in LOVE with the entire retro feeling and worldbuilding. My main issues are with the plot which gets sort of convoluted after SO many anti-climaxes, and all the bits that feel like self-indulgent padding. 

 I loved how much this ISN'T like any sequel to Alien. It is NOT a FPS and there is no way to kill the alien or really do anything to it. Even though we see it frequently (it is burned into my retinas) the fear of it doesn't really go away-- even though I played it only on medium mode. Honestly while I was playing and encountered the alien, it was a huge exercise in patience and deep breaths. Its movement always gave me little jolts since I still am not capable of recognizing when it spots me. Interestingly, I got the feeling several times that it was toying with me (e.g lockers) which was very cool. I understand why some people feel that the xenomorph was "cheating" and zoned in on you, but it makes me feel like I (as the player) am being hunted.  I was scared it could look through the screen. I would like to clarify that the xeno does NOT feel clairvoyant, but it absolutely does feel tethered to you. Personally, I am fine with that because of the whole "if a tree falls in the forest did it really fall" deal-- I WANT TO WITNESS IT! However, some of the best parts for visceral horror were hearing the alien slaughter other people, so more of that could increase the realism. I also like the different kill animations and the lack of pre-programmed jumpscares. 

Surprisingly there were only a few rough patches where I kept dying and had to keep trying, but the frustration did not come from my deaths-- it came from the convoluted plot. The majority of the playing is performing pain-in-the-ass errands that are realistic on a space station that is falling apart, but nonetheless a little frustrating. Especially when my allies are alive and completely useless (pretty sure Samuels was the most helpful).  I really liked having to do errands UNDER PRESSURE (like M18 when priming the release mechanisms or M6/M5) because all the meaningless levers and buttons added to the tension. Sometimes you could see Ripley's hands shaking, and that made me realize why all the stupid tasks in dangerous situations (e.g M18) were so effective at making me feel frustrated, angry and scared all at the same time. I find that when I'm scared, everything is in the way. Opening a door, dialing a phone, etc. all suddenly become incredibly cumbersome with stiff fingers and sweaty palms, which makes the stress even more poignant. It's especially fitting for a game that criticizes bureaucracy and corporate ladders. BUT. I think this was overused in moments where I was not scared at ALL. So pretty much from M10-M14 where it's all dealing with working joes. I genuinely got bored dealing with the tasks AND the synthetics, and I pulled through for the sake of exploring the beautiful map, regardless of the plot padding. 
 
Which brings me to the working joes. Oh boy. They were just annoying, not scary. That was one of the only bits for me that was NOT true to the movie. The humans (especially Seegson Security) were also fairly annoying because I often found myself thinking "why are they still alive with all that noise??". However, I did see a couple of humans get wrecked by the alien without my interference (I only used one noisemaker!). I strongly believe that there should NOT have been that many humans clomping around, just enough to remind the player that people lived at Sevastopol and tug at their heartstrings. I don't really remember where it was but I found a dude cowering by some lockers that really did that, along with the scattered crayon boxes. On the other hand, with the joes it was pretty much hack and slash, which was a nice change of pace sometimes but it just got annoying over time. 

Something I liked was that my choices don't really impact the plot, which freed me up so much to enjoy the game. I also liked the manual save mechanism (maybe a hot take?). It's like that aforementioned "cumbersome fear". It feels sort of like dropping the keys when you're about to get into the car to escape, or when you're sloppily reloading bullets while the enemy gets closer. I've heard some people say that it "broke immersion" which I don't disagree with, but I think it's fine here. They added more tension while saving-- not just because Ripley could die, but also because you could lose all your progress. So that double layered fear was nice. 

On the other hand, I felt that a lot of emotional tension was missing here (especially against the movie). Of course, I do not think the game should be a carbon copy of the movie, but I think the emotional dimension here would have been gorgeous. Especially because there was potential for it and it went unused. Fundamentally, the OG movie is about real people. Here, I got very few moments of visceral horror from Ripley, especially on all the human bodies. There were just a remark or two, but as a player it is very easy to get used to the dead people and not treat them how a person in that situation really would. I think the game could have used a few more of those reminders to snap players out of their distance (re more of the Alien killing people and hearing the screaming from afar). I also would have liked to see more from the human NPCs and the allies! Especially the allies. For a lot of the tasks I was thinking about how they could be done by two people, and how that could raise the stakes even more. Thinking back to Alien, it's very hard to think of parts where the fate of Ellen Ripley was only dependent on her. A lot of the fear comes from the uncertainty of teamwork (e.g Lambert and Parker when Lambert does not move). Even with Jonesy, there's always someone to watch out for which helps add another layer of emotional tension-- the whole "will she or won't she?" bit when Ellen goes back for Jones is awesome. I mean, I found one of the most intense parts of the game to be M5/M6 in San Cristobal, because of Taylor weighing on my mind. I would have loved some character development too! I got flashes of personality, but they were mostly archetypal or just scratching at the surface. Alien (1979) does a great job of subtle but organic character arcs, which I found sort of missing. Especially because there is so much! All the voice logs, the journals, are RICH for reactions from Ripley and all the idiots in her headset. Also I HATE all their lip-synching but that's a 0.000001 concern. 

I also think another issue is time pressure. The only time pressure I experienced was with Samuels and on the Anesidora, and there were only consequences on the Anesidora. I assume in-game this is less than 24 hrs of hell for Ripley, but I do not feel that pressure at ALLLLL (note: I am a slow player). I also hated the whole derelict cutscene, bogged down the game for me. 

SO TOTAL RATING!!

Graphics: 10/10
Map: 10/10 
Soundtrack: 10/10
Antagonists: 9.5/10 (it is called ALIEN not 50% alien 40% working joes 10% humans)
Plot: 4/10 
Characters: 6/10

Overall amazing game!

Alien: Isolation is the perfect game for anyone who wants to relive the terror of the original Alien movie. You'll have to rely on your wits, your motion tracker, and your ability to hide under furniture for extended periods of time.

The graphics are stunning, but you won't have much time to appreciate them because the Xenomorph is always lurking around the corner, waiting to pounce. The sound is also top-notch, so be sure to use a good sound system or headphones – nothing like the sound of a Xenomorph breathing down your neck to make you jump out of your seat.

Overall, this game is a solid 9/10. The only downside is that it can feel like you're stuck in a locker simulator at times, but that's a small price to pay for the sheer terror you'll experience. So if you're looking for a good scare, grab a copy of Alien: Isolation and prepare to be traumatized – in the best possible way.

136561018.review:
This game is about being stuck in a haunted house with a xenomorph on the loose. It is not so much a game as it is a colonoscopy simulator. When that damn alien shows up, you will clench tighter than a xenomorph's sphincter.

The game is set in the future, where the only way to travel through space is to be stalked by a hissing, drooling, acid-blooded killing machine. You play as Amanda Ripley, daughter of the series' iconic protagonist, Ellen Ripley. And just like her mother, Amanda has a knack for getting into trouble.

The game's main objective is to avoid the alien at all costs, which is easier said than done. The alien has some serious anger issues and a tendency to pop out of vents like a surprise party from hell. It is like playing hide and seek with a homicidal maniac who has a degree in hiding.

The game's graphics are stunning, with the space station looking so realistic you can almost smell the recycled air. The sound design is also top-notch, with every creak and groan making you jump like a cat on a hot tin roof.

This is a thrilling experience that will have you on the edge of your seat, as long as you do not fall off from fear. Just remember, in space, no one can hear you scream, but your neighbors sure can.

136351688.review:
I have completed this game way back in 2016 while I was browsing across and realized I havent reviewed any games before but i have some nostalgic feeling attached to it so thought must give it a try.

May contain Potential Spoilers. I would also recommend watching  below 2 Movies before proceeding or thinking of purchasing the title as it will add thrilling and elements to it.

1. Alien (directed by Ridley Scott)
2. Aliens- Directors Cut (directed by James Cameron) 

Further to the note, The game is set 15 years after the events of the original Alien film, and follows Amanda Ripley, the daughter of Ellen Ripley, as she investigates the disappearance of her mother. The gameplay revolves around stealth, exploration, and resource management, as players must avoid the alien and other enemies while completing objectives.

One of the strengths of Alien: Isolation is its atmosphere. Boy o Man you gotta love it, The game does an excellent job of capturing the claustrophobic and tense feel of the original Alien film. The sound design and graphics are top-notch, and the use of lighting and shadows creates an eerie and unsettling environment.

The AI of the alien is also a standout feature. It's unpredictable and relentless, and players must constantly be on their guard to avoid detection. This creates a sense of tension and fear that is rare in modern horror games. Players must use the environment to their advantage, hiding behind objects, crawling through vents, and using distractions to avoid the alien's gaze. The game's mechanics are designed to create tension and fear, with players never quite sure when the alien will strike.

The story is engaging, and the voice acting is top-notch. The game also includes several nods to the original Alien film, which fans of the series will appreciate.

Well i must say its a perfect Horror Genre to ever exist "G.O.A.T". But according to my analysis there is One potential downside of the game. There are additional modes and DLC some players may find the overall package a bit thin. Guess it wont matter unless you're a true Alien fan.   

Overall, Alien: Isolation is an excellent survival horror game that captures the spirit of the original Alien film. The atmosphere, AI, and story are all top-notch, and the game is a must-play for fans of the horror genre.

A true justice to the Alien Franchise and Ellen Ripley. 

Absolutely Nerve touching. 

~

The game also gives you a lot of possibilities in how to handle each situation. You can usually go for a stealthy approach, a violent approach, or something in between.

I'm not going to mention the exact flaws i saw since it may ruin your experience but it's basically the developers trying a little too hard to make everyone's experience of the game identical which is usual for AAA  games so it's not like such a big deal the game is still worth it in my opinion.

135720231.review:
Alien is one of my top 5 movies of all time. I first played this game in 2014, but I quit an hour in because I was too damn scared.

I came back in 2023 with the following conditions:
- Play with a controller so I can sit further back from the screen
- Resist the impulse to explore: Go directly to every objective to reduce exposure to the alien
- Play on easy difficulty
- Bay's Alien Overhaul: This mod changes the Xenomorph's behavior to be less predictable and tedious, making it more "realistic" instead of feeling like he's only stalking YOU (A bit of a difficulty increase, but reduces tedium)

I was finally able to man up and beat the game, and it was a great experience. If you love Alien and/or survival horror, this game won't disappoint you.

Seeing and interacting with the Xenomorph, possibly the coolest creature ever seen in a movie, is the highlight of the game. The space station aesthetics and atmosphere capture the first Alien movie perfectly and really draw you in. The visuals in this game are fantastic.

The sound design is incredible. Hearing the alien crawl around in the vents above your head while you're navigating the station will make your hair stand up on end. Headphones are recommended.

The sheer terror of the first several hours eventually gives way to a manageable dread at a certain point in the game (which I won't spoil). I wish I had played on Normal or even Hard, but I didn't know in advance how much the terror and difficulty would drop.

My only gripes with the game:
- Some objective points were hard to locate, causing me to have to search a room 2-3 times to find things. This can be irritating because you might get killed while you're looking for something that's in plain view. One time I had to look up how to exit a room, only for the walkthrough to tell me that there was a ladder 5 feet in front of my face. I always have this problem in games, though, so it might be a "me" thing.
- Item switching doesn't slow or pause time. A few of my deaths (i.e. checkpoint restarts) could have been avoided if I had an extra 1-2 seconds to pull out a specific item that I needed.
- Crafting some items takes 6+ components, which requires double the number of clicks (arrow buttons + X button). I may have missed something, but that's way too many clicks to craft a molotov cocktail.
- The main character's voice acting was mediocre.

This game is almost a decade old and frequently goes on deep discount. I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a super immersive stealth/horror game.

135241550.review:
This game came out during a moment in the Alien franchise when the essence of the original movie was lost to the space marine action formula. Creative Assembly learned from the horror games genre revival, and made the xenomorph scary again. Not only is the creature genuinely terrifying, but the attention to detail that was put into the scenario is simply phenomenal. In the movie, the spaceship was an integral character of the story, with its claustrophobic corridors and gritty aesthetics that made you feel trapped and unconfortable. That same retro vibe is perfectly translated to the game. The tight spaces, the technology, the gadgets, the sounds, textures and flikering lights, the sensation of being observed and followed, cornered like a rat, not knowing when the creature will come from to end you. In terms of atmosphere, tension, level design and enemy AI, this is hands down the best Alien game that could have existed. 
If I had to point some defect, though, I'd say that the main story is a bit too long, and the missions start to feel repetitive after some hours. Too many errands going from A to B to C, turning generators and talking to key people that give you yet another task. It feels dragging after a while, which is a pity in a game that hits the spot in every other department. Still, a hugely enjoyable experience if you are a fan of horror games or the alien franchise, or both. Still holds up wonderfully almost a decade later.

135212998.review:
[h1]Alien: Isolation[/h1]

As a Decepticon warrior and loyal servant of Megatron, I must say that it was difficult to fully immerse myself in the world of Alien: Isolation. While the game did an admirable job of recreating the claustrophobic, terror-filled environment of the Nostromo, I found myself constantly frustrated by the fact that I, Starscream, could easily defeat a single Xenomorph.

In the game, the Xenomorph is presented as an unstoppable killing machine, a relentless predator that is all but invincible. But as a Transformer, I possess the strength, speed, and weaponry necessary to take on even the most fearsome opponents. It was hard to suspend my disbelief and get fully invested in the experience when I knew that, in real life, I could easily dispatch one of these creatures with ease.

That being said, I can't deny that Alien: Isolation is a masterclass in survival horror. The tension is thick, the atmosphere is oppressive, and the Xenomorph's AI is truly impressive. Even as someone who feels confident in their ability to defeat one of these creatures, I found myself on the edge of my seat, heart pounding, as I tried to evade the creature's deadly grasp.

Overall, while I can't say that Alien: Isolation fully transported me into its world, I can still appreciate the game's craftsmanship and its ability to keep me on the edge of my seat. If you're a fan of survival horror, or just looking for a game that will keep you up at night, Alien: Isolation is definitely worth checking out.

135180093.review:
While horror games and survival elements aren't usually my thing, I was surprised by how fresh and interesting Alien: Isolation still felt in 2023. Despite the graphics and visual effects showing their age, the game looks better than most current "AAA" projects. I watched the original movie a long time ago and I still got chills from hearing the musical theme. Plus, the game had plenty of scary moments to keep me on edge.

The animations and interactions with objects and the environment were done in a way that constantly kept me on my toes. Coming from modern games with casual stealth, I was impressed by how smart the AI was here. Humans and androids could be fooled, but the Alien was relentless and would quickly catch me if I made a wrong move. As a result, I spent most of the time hiding and sneaking, frantically checking the motion sensor.

However, by the second half of the game, this gameplay loop started to become tiresome. At times, the alien seemed to be camping outside my hiding spot, forcing me to crawl back and forth for extended periods. This was especially frustrating when I had run out of resources and had to scavenge every cabinet in the area. While I'm not a fan of looting in games, crafting was essential as each device had a specific use.

There were a few drawbacks to the game:
-Backtracking with enemy respawns felt unnecessary and tedious. Just added more hiding hustle.
-Some doors were closed and special equipment was required, but after receiving the item I mostly couldn't remember how many doors to open are left. Some locations just got forgotten. 
-Towards the end of the game, the game throws in shooting mechanics only to take them away shortly after. This rollercoaster ride of gameplay could be jarring for some players. 
-The most common task was to turn on the generator, which became repetitive and tedious in the final stages.

Overall, while the ending of the game felt drawn out I still found Alien: Isolation to be a very cool product.

Great game but there is one major flaw, which for some reason people love, which is the aliens AI.

The alien appears extremely often and at times it feels impossible to play because the alien will be there randomly, blocking your way. I hope that if the game is ever remastered or a new release is done, that the interactions with the alien are more scripted or they are more rare but maybe have bigger consequences on how you need to play when encountering it. The atmosphere, risk and tension is really what captured the essence in the movies, but it's really lacking in the game.

134342630.review:
Alien: Isolation, a survival horror game released back in 2014. This game is set in the same universe as the famous Alien franchise, and it does a great job of capturing the atmosphere and tension of the films.

First and foremost, let's talk about the graphics. The developers did an excellent job of creating a believable and immersive world that feels like it belongs in the Alien universe. The lighting and sound design are top-notch, and the attention to detail is impressive. You can almost feel the cold metal of the space station and the dampness of the air vents. 

Now, let's move on to the gameplay. Alien: Isolation is a true survival horror game that emphasizes stealth and evasion over combat. The main antagonist, the xenomorph, is a formidable foe that will hunt you down relentlessly throughout the game. You must use all of your wits and resources to evade it, distract it, or hide from it. The game's pacing is slow and deliberate, with moments of tension and terror interspersed throughout. It's not a game for those who prefer fast-paced action or a constant stream of jump scares. But for those who appreciate a well-crafted horror experience, Alien: Isolation is a gem.

Finally, let's talk about the story. The game takes place 15 years after the events of the original Alien film and follows Amanda Ripley, the daughter of Ellen Ripley, as she searches for clues about her mother's disappearance. The story is engaging and well-written, with plenty of twists and turns to keep you invested.

In conclusion, Alien: Isolation is a must-play for fans of the Alien franchise and survival horror games in general. It's a slow-burning, tense, and terrifying experience that will keep you on the edge of your seat. The graphics, gameplay, and story are all top-notch, making this a game that's definitely worth your time.

134268743.review:
[b]From my achievements:[/b]

[u]"You Shouldn't Be There"[/u]
Complete the fourth mission
Unlocked 2 Jan, 2018 @ 6:01pm

[u]"How Do You Feel?"[/u]
Complete the fifth mission
Unlocked 2 Mar, 2023 @ 4:26pm

Yes. Mission 5 is the first one where you really face the alien. And yes, it took me over 5 years to grow some balls and go back to actually play and finishing the game in hard difficulty.

I've played so many survival horrors. And I think this is the only one that actually made feel so anxious... it's the adrenaline of knowing you cannot beat that thing and you have to hide, but at the same time, knowing you have to keep moving, and hiding in a locker forever is useless. This game is a masterpiece but definitely not for everyone.

Personally, I don't like this kind of survival. I also tried Outlast in the past and hated it... but I love the movie so much that I had to really experience this. The way the game has been developed showing a huge respect and love for the first movie is unbelievable. From the design of the space station and ships, to the OST, and all those interactions with the machines and computers you need to do, that look so much like everything in the movie (Including the sound they emit, the keys... really resembling that opening scene of the film).

The game has probably the best sound that I've ever hear in a video game.

And for a game that it's going to be a decade old, it looks amazing. It's really fun how this game can run at fixed 144fps while looking amazing, and some new games run like absolute garbage and look worse. I'm no expert regarding programming... but seriously, the reflections in this game are simply perfect with zero impact in the performance (RTX I'm looking at you), all the effects, the lighting and shadows, the fire, the fog on the floor in some areas... It's just so beautiful.

9.5/10

133907609.review:
Oh boy, where do I start? Alien: Isolation is a game that will make you scream, cry, and possibly pee your pants. But trust me, it's worth it. Here are several reasons to play this terrifyingly awesome game:

It's like being in your very own horror movie! You get to explore a creepy abandoned spaceship, hide from a terrifying alien, and try not to die in the process. What's not to love?

The sound effects are so realistic that you'll be looking over your shoulder every five seconds. Every creak and squeak of the spaceship will have you on the edge of your seat, and that's not even mentioning the sounds the alien makes when it's hunting you down. shudders

The graphics are top-notch. The dark, gritty atmosphere of the spaceship is so well done that you'll forget you're even playing a game. You'll feel like you're actually there, being stalked by a murderous alien.

The tension is palpable. You'll be sneaking around, trying not to make any noise, and then BAM! The alien comes out of nowhere and your heart jumps out of your chest. It's like playing a game of hide-and-seek with your worst nightmare.

The storyline is fantastic. You play as Amanda Ripley, the daughter of Ellen Ripley (the main character from the Alien movies). You're on a mission to find out what happened to your mother, and in the process, you get caught up in a nightmare of your own.

So if you're ready for some heart-stopping terror, then Alien: Isolation is the game for you!

133408061.review:
[h3]Alien: Isolation[/h3]

is a very strong Horror-Game with a terrifying Atmosphere and clearly one of the best ones when it comes to the Aspect of delivering it to the Players in almost every Environment it has to offer.
Following the Character with the Name Amanda Ripley, the daughter of Ellen Ripley from the Game’s Inspiration Movie-Franchise of *ALIEN*, Players will be put into very dangerous Situations while hoping to survive and to find Information about the whereabouts of the lost Ship Nostromo and its Crew.

Through Vents and corridors and a lot of Locations of an almost abandoned Station it goes, with the constant Pressure of the Presence of a hostile Alien that knows nothing better to do than to hunt Humans and drag them away.
Players have different Options to maneuver from Area to Area by using different Types of Tools to either confuse the Xenomorph or lure it away for a while.
But don’t get fooled yourself, this Enemy cant be killed and will always be a threat to the Protagonists survival and progress.

The Game’s strength is definitely the Atmosphere that gives a constant feeling of Danger due to the Presence of a hunting Alien that does not need to hide or to scare Jump.
In the Game’s Case its the Player who has to hide in order to survive the Encounters and not be seen.
As specially when playing the Game on Nightmare-Difficulty with even more limited Resources and a partly defected Motion-Tracker, Players are able to get the absolute Essence of Horror from the dark and almost completly abandoned Sevastopol-Station and the Journey through this Adventure.

Despite of its great Atmosphere tho, the Game has a weakspot. It is a little bit to short for such an Amazing Environment. It could have done more with a huge Station like it has introduced, but decided to go straight trough the Main-Story.
Not that this is bad, but after finishing it on the highest Difficulty, there is simply nothing new to it.
Still, its a solid Horror-Game experience.

I recommend this Game to Players who like scary Horror Atmospheres in Games and for Fans of the Alien (Xenomorph) Franchise.
---------------------------------
[h3]Points i give this Game (average Points 8,56 / 10):[/h3]
8,9 / 10 Graphic (Amazing graphics and Animations and a lots of Details in each Environment)
8,4 / 10 Gameplay (Game tends to surprise with even more Tools to use from and more dangers to avoid)
7,2 / 10 Story (It has a good Story and well implemented Dialogues, but was a little bit short, could have been far longer Story there.)
8 / 10 Soundtrack (Totally Nostalgia for Fans of the ALIEN Movie. It fits the Atmosphere perfectly)
9 / 10 Enemies (The constant Situation of getting hunted by the Alien really shows in the way it is doing it. Looking around and under and into covers, choosing different paths to not let the Player abuse some patterns. Without that Xeno, the Game wouldn’t be what it is.)
8,4 / 10 Environment (Well made Environment, with a lot of Details, to go through and to try to stay alive in while scavenging for Materials.)
10 / 10 ALIEN-Franchise worthy (This Game is clearly the best Videogame Adaptation of the Movie Franchise so far and really gives the vibes that can be felt when watching the first Movie the first Time)

133243725.review:
Voted down with a heavy heart. I wanted to love this very much. As an aesthetic experience, it's doing interesting, high-quality stuff. As a videogame, it quickly grows frustrating and boring. I quit less than halfway through and watched the rest on youtube.

If you get spotted, you die. This kind of first-person stealth just isn't fun. To design a 20-hour game around this mechanic is really wild. I applaud Creative's ambition, but I don't think they solved that core problem. 

It's a beautiful moment when the alien first makes its entrance. My nails had never been more raggedly bitten. But, a few hours later, I had seen every death animation ten times each and just didn't care anymore. I was sick of staring blandly at the inside of locker doors, waiting for the footsteps outside to go away so I could get back out there and fiddle the thingy.

It's possible my frustrating experience was partly my own fault. I first set the game to Hard, identifying as a capital-G Gamer and lover of sci-fi horror. I wanted a more visceral, edge-of-seat experience. But the danged thing can get into the vents on hard mode! As my frustration grew, I thought about starting over on Normal, but the damage had been done. If you play this, don't make the same mistake I did, and keep things easy. Instant death mechanics are punishing enough.

All that said, I would love for Creative to try this again. This game has atmosphere in spades. If they can find a way to fix the problems with first-person stealth, or just diversify the gameplay more, something like this could easily become a mainstream classic, rather than just of the cult variety.

Overall, a fantastic game, true to its roots. It borrows from the first two films, primarily. Great visuals...lots of film grain, "camera effects" type stuff. It has a unique look. Great "on-rails" narrative, single-player survival game. My only critiques would be as follows: 
1. Too few save points...it can get frustrating dying, then having to replay 10 minutes of the game to get back to where you died.
2. Towards the end of the game, it felt like the devs were really milking the duration of the narrative...making you complete meaningless, repetitive activities to stretch out the playtime. It isn't too bad, but there were some groans from me towards the end..."oh, great...now I get to walk back across the catwalk AGAIN for two minutes." 
3. I know that this is, at least in part, an homage to the source material, but they really leaned hard into the false endings. Towards the end, I just wanted to finish the game, and it lost some of its shine for me...and I'm a super die-hard Alien franchise fan. 

Apart from that, this game is AMAZING. Superb sound design. Get this game. You'll enjoy it.

I some how have over 30 hours on record for this game, despite only playing through fully once.

The reason for that is, as an Alien fanatic, this game checked every box for me but it scared me so deeply that I could never play it. I played through the first couple of hours about half a dozen times but as soon as I started to get stalked by the Alien I'd quit. I couldn't handle the stress. That thing feels alive. It's terrifying. I never thought I'd come close to feeling like Ripley did but boy does Creative Assembly do an insanely good job of giving you a taste of what it feels like to be stalked by a highly intelligent, malevolent monster.

Thankfully, so determined was I that I would fully, finally experience this masterpiece (and it is a masterpiece; and utter, solid gold one at that) that I started training myself to play scarier and scarier games. I worked my way through them, like a heavyweight working his way through the division before he was ready to challenge the champion. Eventually, I'd trained all I could and I tackled the best there was. I won. With the help of a guide, plenty of pairs of clean underwear and a healthy amount of breaks to catch my breath, I won. 

If you like being scared sh*tless and you like Aliens - this is the best it gets. It's a breathtaking achievement. Still can't believe that IGN review.

133113877.review:
[b]Graphics and story[/b] 10/10

[i]Alien: Isolation[/i] is a horror game. This is the story of Amanda Ripley. While she was working, Christopher Samuels will arrive and inform her about retrieval of black box from the Nostromo ship. It was salvaged by the Anesidora ship and is now in ownership of the Seegson Corporation at the Sevastopol space station. Amanda wants to suss what happened to her mother on that ship. So journey to the space station begins with an access ticket to the [i]Torrens[/i] ship. Upon arrival in Sevastopol after a spacewalk, she finds that the station is almost empty. Communications fail, looters are hostile, androids turn enemies, and a perilous enemy prowls in air ducts as well as in every corner of the station. She will do everything possible to abscond, the ending of which is unexpected, abstruse and open. 

The design of the game follows a lot of visual and artistic design based on the [i]Alien[/i] movie by Ridley Scott. We can appreciate details of the interior design composed by human technology. It has an insightful combination between different spatial dimensions of each place based on symmetrical and structuralism design with the variation of lighting on the predominant white colour. The interior of the Torrens, the places in Sevastopol and its exterior are extremely well cared for. Without forgetting the special effects in sounds and in reverberation, with which it evokes nostalgia and fear when remembering the film. Outside: we can undergo petrifying darkness of space, while in background orbit a giant gas planet KG-348. There, in the distance, perplexed, the bright star barely illuminates enveloping darkness. The game preserves the biotechnological art of H. R. Giger. It maintains the artistic design of Alien and its ship. This is a contrast that I like: the human design (formal and cold) and the alien design (organic and sinister).

The game also has a good direction in photography. That can be seen in every cinematographic shot, hence it is guided according to the narrative, in such a way that a step-by-step immersion is present as we enter the story. Also, this creative idea of narrative layers allows for better character development within the plot. We experience Amanda's story, the (hi)story of Sevastopol's past, and anecdote of survivors before and after contact with the xenomorph. All the characters develop and end tragically at each step of our journey into the plot. Something that caught my attention was the fiction of androids with their artificial intelligence controlled by Apollo. We can tell difference between them with humans through their gestures and behaviours. Androids don't have facial expressions and with that it allows us to bond more with Amanda and Christopher, even though he's an android too. It is worth noting the feeling of vulnerability before the Alien. A powerful, invincible and terrifying enemy. How fragile is the human. All of that maintains the genuine essence of the Alien story.

[b]Playability[/b] 10/10

As the game is based on the Ridley Scott movie, we'll be facing a powerful and immortal enemy. Although androids and humans will also become foes. The intent of the game is to feel horror and vulnerability, so the gameplay focuses on survival and stealth. The ideal is to balance both gameplay modes, but that will depend on each player.

Stealth mode will be an important game mode. We'll make less noise when walking in a crouch, since when running there is necessary risk of being located by enemies. They also make a lot of clatter and racket, so it will be easy to notice their presence. But if the Alien grabs us, death is instant. There is action of leaning out, in case we're waiting for enemy to move in another direction. The air ducts and switches to activate vapour, alarms or open doors, all of this will allow us to find routes to avoid frenemy. In case someone locates us, there is option to run; but the Alien is too fast, so lockers and some «boxes» can be used to hide us. Inside we'll hold our breath and avoid moving so as not to be detected. To complement the stealth mode, a small portable detector was added. With that we can detect enemies as well as allow us to orient ourselves in correct direction of the objective.

But if we go into struggle, the use of self-defence will be necessary. There is always the option to shun any enemy. Five weapons that we can use, but they have limited ammo. Each weapon, as the game indicates, is a type of tool that inflicts damage to a type of enemy. On the other hand, we can loot pieces with which it will allow us to craft objects from diagrams found in certain places in the game. There are seven in total, they can be enhanced and each of those are nifty to cause a distraction, repel attack or stun. 

There is a third gameplay, but this is linked to the essence and character of Amanda Ripley. Since she's an engineer, she'll know how to survive, is agile and knowledgeable. Common in-game activities related to Amanda's personality are: starting controls, opening doors by welding, and hacking. This last activity will permit us to use a device with which we'll access doors, computers and controls. It has small puzzles in the form of a mini-game. Remember to read the notes on computer, as it contains important info. This is something I loved about the game: the character is linked to the gameplay, it is concise, coherent and logical.

[b]Music and FX[/b] 10/10

About the soundtrack I will be brief due to the length of the review as it is a good idea to listen to the music in the game. Something worth noting first is the game's sound effects. It preserves the sounds that computers produce, the muffled noises inside the space helmet, and the beeps of alarms. Something that is inevitably noticed are the surround sounds, binaural type, with which our environment is perceived. It offers an immersive experience. This sound effect will allow music to seep into every pore of our soul.

About the soundtrack, I understand that it was composed by Christian Henson, Joe Henson and Alexis Smith. The idea is to recover the melody heard in Scott's film. The music fits perfectly into each segment of the narrative, it does so through magnificent timing. The form of music is to reveal the horrors that jealously guard the dark space. This is achieved in many moments of the game through background music with drone-dark ambient and space ambient. Silence predominates to give way to the introduction of suspenseful spatial narrative the sound of flutes. In the moments where it generates tension of horror and anxiety, we'll listen to it in synchronization of the alien with orchestral music. This is done through powerful string instruments and percussion. Or when detected whose music consists of rhythms similar to heartbeats. Listening to it reminded me a lot of the movie, it's quite an interesting piece of work.

[b]Duration[/b] 10/10

The duration depends on the way each player enters the game. It is made up of 18 missions. But we won't notice because of the fluidity or continuity of the story. We will have wall phones for game saves. It keeps us waiting for the horror, but also to continue exploring on the space station. It has various difficulties and a survival mode. Also, there are some DLCs, but we don't really need them to enjoy this game in its entirety. Alien movie fan or not, I highly recommend this game for its original story, gameplay, art, and design.

[h1]Recommendation: 10/10[/h1]

133110349.review:
I know it is heresy to dislike this game, and I assure you I nowhere near hate it. I was just... bored.

In recent years I have grown a massive addiction to survival horror titles; Resident Evil 1, 4 and Evil Within 2 being my personal highlights. So I feel my opinion will hopefully hold some gravity. The opening couple of hours are exciting, being able to explore the ship and the grand build up to the reveal of the alien were really fun and tense. Yet once the Xenomorph becomes your stalker enemy, things really got tiring and fairly frustrating. The game became a mixture of hiding and luring over, and over again. If other people enjoy that, then more power to them, I wish I had that sort of patience. I hope you might like it, I want nothing more than the Alien franchise to be a success once again.

132746511.review:
You might have read this already, but this is certainly the best Alien game ever made. I also posit this is the only good walking simulator ever made, as combat is discouraged, yet intense, and you'll be reading plenty of logs and listening to tapes constantly to understand the lore. Plus, you are bound to get scared. I'm not one to get scared by games, but this one caught me off guard many times. 

Sadly the game is not perfect, although it almost was. I don't wanna be a party pooper and spoil the game, but the devs broke some promises along the way, and the ending leaves much to be desired. There's also a segment that was clearly meant to put you face to face with a queen, but there was none. That's all I will say about the subject. 

It's a superb game campaign-wise. I dunno about the optional content outside of the two additional campaigns, which are pretty decent, albeit short experiences. In terms of visuals, sound design, presentation (even the 20th Century Fox ad gives me the chills), the game is outstanding and will leave you craving for more, even though it's fairly long, but not unnecessarily drawn out. This is tied to some of the broken promises I mentioned, but it's not that big of a deal.

132678513.review:
Alien: Isolation is a fairly decent horror game. Like many games I play nowadays, it is not particularly bad while also not being particularly great. No features or gameplay elements stand out all too much, but there's also no glaring issues that hold back the game from being enjoyable; only minor bumps in the road.

You have three types of enemies; the alien, the rouge androids, and other humans. I see it as quite a bit of a cliche to have humans as enemies, especially since I don't see it making sense in this games plot. I can understand that, say, in a post-apocalyptic world that people would be pitted against each other for resources. But on the Nostromo it seems very much more of a 'us V.S the Alien' type of situation. But maybe I missed something in the story between the big playtime gap I had from the first third and the last two thirds of the game. In terms of gameplay, I didn't like encountering the humans. It was generally annoying to sneak around them for long periods of time, and the game fails at being able to distinguish allies from enemies since they all wear the same clothing. I would walk into a room and hide from everyone, only to find out that they're all friendly. Then I would walk into the next room and I'm staring down the barrel of a shotgun.

The rouge androids are alright. They certainly have an ominous and intimidating demeanour to them (to the point that you question how someone made this without realising how creepy they are) but they don't pose very much of a threat. They do have the capacity to soak up quite a few bullets before falling, so it's advised to try and avoid them as much as you to conserve on resources. But they're so slow that if you do get caught you can usually just run away before they ever create any legitimate problems for you.

The alien is obviously the star of the show. The alien will spend most of it's time crawling around in the vents, bumping around above you as you try to pinpoint it's position using the motion tracker. It creates this great sense of fear an ominousness. The developers really understood the idea that an enemy is more scary when you can't fully see them, and don't have all the information at your disposal, but still allowed the motion tracker to assist the player in feeling like the game isn't being unfair. If the alien spots you while on the ground, it'll charge at you so fast that most weapons won't be able to stop it. Only the flamethrower and Molotov are very effective at stopping it, which pressures the player into resource management even more so.

I do like that, for the non-human enemy types, is isn't necessarily just pure survival horror. You do have some capacity to defend yourself, but resorting to that as your only means of getting around will quickly fail as you run out of equipment.

I do feel that there can often times be an overabundance of materials to create items. Maybe I just didn't use items as often as I should have been, but I often found that I was maxed out on most materials about halfway through the game.

There were also some points in the game where it was incredibly hard to navigate due to level design and map layout. In one section, due to randomly opening doors and overlapping floors, I had to refer to a walkthrough just to get around because I had no idea which doors would and wouldn't open.

But yeah, generally a decent horror game despite some minor complaints. I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys horror games a lot, especially since you can pick it up for quite cheap nowadays.

3 out of 5

132664800.review:
An exceptionally well executed horror game in all aspects. The game oozes with atmosphere and looks incredible for a game of its time that you can make look even nicer with some engine tweaks and super resolution. The mood and lighting of scenes is so well done, and the general vibes of being in space and on a space station are such a treat. The build-up to key events is fantastic, and the game does an amazing job of keeping nearly every moment tense and demanding you to be on your toes at all times. 

Alien Isolation really does an excellent job at making you feel only *just* powerful enough to scrape by, which makes threats actually threatening and keeps that element of fear and risk in play at all times. The Alien is an absolute menace and can only be stalled for so long; you *will* need to keep moving, and you'll need to do so in a calculated and careful manner.

Quite possibly a masterpiece in the horror genre; a game that everyone should try.

132524713.review:
What can I say about Alien Isolation that hasn't already been said? That it's a modern classic and presumably the best horror game to come out in recent years? That as a megafan of the original Alien movie, you will really enjoy how it not only is faithful to the source material but expands the world with many interesting ideas and characters that have long since been accepted as canon? That it's a damn shame we'll never get a sequel?

I honestly adore this title and I invite anyone who's curious to pick this up and play it with a nice set of headphones on a pc that can run the best graphical settings. I have also enjoyed the game on PS3 but the extra atmosphere makes all the difference.  Whatever your specs, you'll still get the same amazing gameplay. The art direction is amazing with a retrofuturistic style befitting the universe and equipment and machinery very similar to the original film. If you like the tech in the original film or something like Star Wars, I am sure you'll be hooked on the aestethic. The titular Alien is a formidable foe, especially on hard mode and while the behaviour is random, it acts by a set rules of engagement that are possible to learn and take advantage of to outsmart the beast and even use it to your advantage. This does admittedly take a bit of the scare away from the monster, as you get better, but your first couple of hours you'll definetely be spending way too much time crouching under tables or hiding in closets and vents. Apparently the monster learns from your behaviour and adapts, but I can't say it's something I've experienced that much in either of my two playthroughs. Both human and android enemies (the latter known as Working Joes) are also sufficiently challenging and creepy, in part because you can never really be sure if they are friend or foe.

Are there snakes in paradise? Yes, but mainly related to the story. Pacingwise the game is far too long. Though not as unbearable the second time around, both the beginning and the ending of the story stretches beyond the necessary, and the goalpost is moved one or two times too many for things to still be exciting. I think it'd been better to have a shorter but more focused experience, even if that would mean rearranging certain story beats. It could all have been forgiven had the ending been good, but sadly I just find it very lacklustre, in part because the main character Amanda Ripley never really gets time to be fleshed out as a character and also because of an annoying last minute twist. The new characters are a mixed back, with the android Samuels and the spacer Marlow as stand outs. I also experienced some age signs with the game: audio doesn't always sync perfectly, there was a bit of screen tearing at points and sometimes the character model clipped through surfaces, showed the edge where the arm met the invisible torso, left floating wrenches and guns hanging in the air, shook violently and other such quirks, that did poke holes in the illusion.

That however does not change the fact that I enjoy being immersed in this universe, and there is still a lot of replayability left. Should I try the grueling "Nightmare Mode" where the alien has heightened senses and starts with knowing more search strategies, and where you take more damage from gunshots, have a faulty motion tracker and no minimap? Should I dip my toes into survival mode, where you play as side characters discovering even more of the space station while avoiding the alien in a fun challenge mode? Should I replay the DLC taking place on the Nostromo with voices by the original cast (where I must say, that I find Crew Expendable a bit disappointing...) Or should I do a roleplay focused playthrough, where I rely mostly on gadgets and never kill a human being (which is totally possible) while really searching the Sevastopol for the hidden Nostromo logs? I can't wait to see, but I am also prepared to take in the good with the bad.

132342601.review: I own this game on my Switch and on Steam. I have played it to the point that I know each map and level like the back of my hand. I have immense respect for the developers for staying faithful to the universe in terms of story and aesthetics. Although at this point the game is now almost 9 years old, it is still visually stunning, and an absolute treat to launch myself into. At no point am I bored during this game. At no point do I wish I could skip a section. And despite knowing the game inside and out, at no point am I not terrified while the Xeno is active. The AI is incredibly smart, and really does make you feel like you need to constantly crouch your way around for fear of accidentally giving away where you currently are. The story flows beautifully, with moments of respite to catch your breath, but you will at other times be forced into small sections where it's just you, and one angry Xeno out for blood. There are so many things that I can say about this game that I haven't already, like getting back the cast of the original movie for some new never-before heard dialogue. The attention to detail, the care and craftsmanship put into this game, but I could never do the game enough justice. Simply put, whether or not you're a fan of the Alien universe, or just a survival horror fan, this game is 100% worth your time and money. I genuinely believe it is one of the best games of the 2010's

132100868.review:
Alien: Isolation is a highly acclaimed survival-horror video game developed by Creative Assembly and published by Sega, which takes inspiration from the classic 1979 movie Alien. The game effectively builds upon the world, characters, and scenery from the original movie, offering fans of the franchise a new and exciting way to experience the Alien universe.

One of the standout features of Alien: Isolation is its intense and suspenseful gameplay, which is set aboard the maze-like space station known as Sevastopol. Players take on the role of Amanda Ripley, daughter of Ellen Ripley, as they navigate the station while being hunted by a deadly Xenomorph. The game's AI system is highly advanced, allowing the Xenomorph to actively search for the player and react to their actions in real-time, making each encounter feel unique and unpredictable.

Another positive aspect of Alien: Isolation is its stunning visuals and sound design, which effectively capture the atmosphere of the original movie. The game features highly detailed environments aboard Sevastopol, excellent use of lighting, and a top-notch soundtrack that effectively captures the feeling of being lost in space and under attack by a dangerous alien creature.

The game also features a compelling storyline that is true to the source material. With its well-written characters, immersive world-building, and unexpected twists, Alien: Isolation is a true love letter to the Alien franchise and builds upon the classic movie in exciting and meaningful ways.

Overall, Alien: Isolation is a highly enjoyable and memorable survival-horror game that offers fans of the Alien franchise a new and exciting way to experience the world, characters, and scenery from the original movie. If you are a fan of the Alien franchise or enjoy survival-horror games, then Alien: Isolation is definitely worth checking out.

Alien and Aliens are both tow of my favorite movies of all time, with the preference to Alien. This is the best piece of Alien related entertainment since Aliens, in my opinion.

132072080.review:
It starts strong and gets weaker the longer it goes on.
Especially at the end they really try to stretch the gametime.

The beginning is really REALLY R-E-A-L-L-Y slow.
The gameplay is really repetitive, but the atmosphere carries it.
The backtracking and  the sometimes unclear way to progress can be annoying
It is a little too long for its own good.

The alien is the most horrifying stalker imaginable and perfect for a horror game.

It has some issues to run probably if you have anything then one 24inch x 1080p screen on Windows 7/8.1, but that can be fixed with an engine config edit.
Don't use the Linux port. It uses a library must displays faced out by now. Install the proton version.

But at the end it is the only good alien game and actually unique in what it is doing when it comes to the alien.

If you're fine with the stretched out last 20-30%, then this is a really good game for you.

131968482.review:
If you're going to play this game, there are a few things to know. Suffice it to say, it is a good game. The sound design, pacing are very on brand for the Alien movies. That said, see below to determine if this is a game you want to play. 

Also, I have a playlist of my play through of the game on youtube, check it out if you like:
https://youtube.com/playlist?list=PLfCTcyJ57ToGVOtHd-Zc1NemBw8QXFxh7

[b][u]Things to Know[/u][/b]
[olist]
    [*]This is primarily a stealth game, the stealth mechanics are also very finicky/busted at times. So there will be built in frustration with that.
    [*]This game is insanely long. Like at least 20 hours if you play perfectly and don't explore, definitely more if you die. There were more than a few times where I thought, "surely this game must be near the end". I was wrong, a lot.
    [*]The atmosphere in this game is amazing, like literally right out of the movies.
    [*]You will get mad at this game. It'll happen. I promise. Just accept that the AI is often BS and keep on going. It's worth it overall.     
[/olist]

131888881.review:
Good game that holds up well for its time. A little buggy, especially with AI that causes a little too much restarts due to poor coding in some areas. The game is long but entertaining throughout for those who enjoy being hunted: having to rely on sound and hiding spots, learning the enemies patterns, keeping quiet at all times, exploring various areas and using the various resources at your disposal. The game also has plenty of lore to find in game for those that are interested.
This game never gets old in my experience. It kept me on the edge of my seat with a lot of close calls and I really enjoy that eventually you receive ways to fight off the xenomorph.
I rate it 8/10, points taken off for the AI bugs only as it did ruin my experience in a few areas. Having to repeat a lot of tasks took the scare factor out and became an irritating chore after 4+ deaths, all due to the game not doing what it was supposed to do.
Overall recommend however, Alien Isolation is a classic horror game that anyone interested in the genre should play.

131876609.review: I always tell people- If you ever wanted to live through the first Alien film, you should play this game. The game is absolutely brilliant- and that Alien AI is an absolute nightmare to deal with- just the way it's suppose to be. As much as I understand, the AI itself was relatively new in the way it worked and remains quite unique to this date. It truly feels like a predator- prey situation. And since it's quite smart and unpredictable (which only gets worse on higher difficulty levels), you have to be strategic and patient in the way you approach every mission. Also- The environments and sound design completely immerse you into the surroundings of this game. Admittedly, I find it hard not to gush over the details and how great of a job they did being true to the design of the films. The DLCs also have a very special place in my heart because of that. The gameplay itself and pacing at certain points can get the tiniest bit repetitive. Yet the unpredictability of the Alien itself gives the game a lot of replay value and keep things relatively fresh. Lastly- most of the characters are a little vanilla too. Ripley herself is quite stoic but it would have been nice to see some more personality from her. The story arc with her mother, Ellen, too barely has an impact on the game. So I do wish the narrative and drama played a stronger role in this game- however that would have been an additional bonus since the game itself is pretty darn close to perfect as is. As a parting note- if you like survival horror as a genre and like the Alien franchise, you will a 100% enjoy this game. And personally, I adore Alien: Isolation and pretty much play it at least once a year.

131761888.review: First let me say that I was spoiled going into this game (I watched a lot of Youtube lets play of this game which was how I became aware of this game).  Although I knew what was going to happen it did not ruin my first time (I consider the medical location to be my actual first since I could not just sneak into a elevator) to actually hide from the alien.  For me this is the first game were my heart was pounding and I think I was just siting under a medical bed for minutes since I was to scared to leave my hiding spot. That said after my second dead the alien became less dreadful but still a little scary scary.  My advice to anyone who is already spoiled and would like to try the game is to use your tracker if you are lost (I got lost so many times since my focus was always "when will the alien drop down").  The tracker will always point to where you have to go and also do not be afraid to use your items.  I am ashamed to say that I think I ended the game with full 3 for each item because I was always uncertain as to when I would actually need them (I did use them but rarely). Overall I do recommend this game even in 2023.
